question_text: All of the following are true about the ministry of AYUSH except:

It aims to mainstream AYUSH as part of the National Rural Health Mission
It was previously known as department of Indian system of medicine and homeopathy
It regulates the fields of Ayurveda, Yoga, Homeopathy and Siddha only
explanation: The Ministry of AYUSH was established to regulate the fields of Ayurveda, Yoga, and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, and Homeopathy. question_text: Who was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848?
explanation: Edwin Chadwick was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848. He was an English lawyer during the 1832 cholera epidemic. It is considered a landmark act in the history of public health.

question_text: Identify the scientist who showed that anthrax was caused by a bacteria.
explanation: Robert Koch discovered that anthrax was caused by bacteria. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. He won the Nobel prize in Physiology in 1905. He also proposed Koch's postulates linking specific microorganisms to specific diseases. They state that the microorganism must be: Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms. Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent The following images show Robert Koch and his drawing of the anthrax bacillus:

question_text: The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease was:
explanation: The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease is leprosy bacillus. In 1873, Armauer Hansen demonstrated Mycobacterium leprae (rod-like bodies) from a leprosy nodule. This is the first time that chronic infectious disease in humans was shown to be related to a bacillus. In 1876, Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax.
subject: PSM

question_text: Max Joseph von Pettenkofer described the concept of:
explanation: Pettenkofer of Munich put forth the theory of multifactorial causation of disease. Other theories of causation of disease include: Spontaneous generation theory - given by Aristotle Web of causation theory - given by MacMahon and Pugh Supernatural theory of disease

question_text: In which country was the last case of naturally occurring smallpox in the world recorded?
explanation: The last case of naturally occurring smallpox was in Somalia in 1977. The last case of smallpox occurred in 1978 when a medical photographer was accidentally exposed to the smallpox virus in a research laboratory in Birmingham. India was declared smallpox-free on 24th May 1975. WHO declared smallpox as eradicated globally on 8th May 1980.
subject: PSM

question_text: Who first coined the term social medicine?
explanation: Jules Guérin coined this term as editor of the Gazette médicale de Paris. He was a French orthopaedist in the mid-1800s. Option A: John Ryle promoted social medicine in England in the early 1900s. Option C: Alfred Grotjahn described social pathology, the social factors influencing diseases. Option D: Francis Albert Eley Crew stated that social medicine stood on the pillars of medicine and sociology.

question_text: How would you define socialized medicine?
options: Subsidized medical care at government's expense
Free medical care provided and regulated by government alone
Free medical care at government expense, regulated by professional groups
Integration of social medicine with health care
explanation: Socialized medicine is the provision of medical service at the government's expense but is operated and regulated by professional groups, and not the government. Russia was the first country to completely socialize medicine. Free medical care by a government alone is called state medicine.
subject: PSM

question_text: All of the following are true about socialized medicine except:
options: Ensures social equity and universal coverage
Use state funds for free medicine
explanation: Increasing the utilization of health services is not a component of socialized medicine. It refers to the provision of medical service through the state funds; however, it is operated and regulated by professional groups. Russia was the first to completely socialize medicine. It eliminates competition among physicians as well as ensures social equity and universal health coverage.

Who said that the secret of national health lies in the homes of people?
Florence Nightingale

question_text: Which of the following is not included in the WHO definition of health?
explanation: According to the WHO, health is “a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity”. In recent years, the definition has been modified to also include the ability to lead a “socially and economically productive life.”
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the biomedical concept of disease based upon?
options: Combination of social, economic and political influences
explanation: The biomedical concept of disease is based on the germ theory of disease, which was postulated by Louis Pasteur. The germ theory of disease states that microorganisms known as pathogens or germs can lead to disease. It was criticized that it did not include environmental, social, psychological, and cultural determinants of health. The ecological concept of disease states that disease is the maladjustment of the human organism to the environment. The psychosocial concept of disease hypothesised that health is also influenced by social, psychological, cultural and economic factors as well. The holistic concept of disease includes all the above concepts to describe health.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
explanation: Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator. A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators. Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.
subject: PSM

question_text: An epidemiologist is tasked with measuring the overall health status of a community using a morbidity indicator. Which of the following indicators will she not use?
options: Number of days of restricted activity
explanation: Number of days of restricted activity is a disability indicator. Morbidity is defined as public health outcomes focusing on diseases, traumas, or injury. Morbidity indicators can be used to measure the overall health and extent of healthcare utilisation in a given population. Disability is defined as public health outcomes related to health conditions that include limitations in personal activities and societal participation. There are two types of disability indicators as follows: Event type indicators- Number of days of restricted activity Bed disability days Work loss days (or school loss days) within a specified period Person type indicators- Limitation of mobility: e.g confined to bed Limitation of activity: e.g limitation to perform the basic activities of daily living such as eating and going to the toilet
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following indicators can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn would be expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality?
explanation: HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality. HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of health states. Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature death. As HALE includes not just disability but the larger definition of poor health, it is a better option with respect to the question.
subject: PSM

question_text: While assessing the health needs of a community, an epidemiologist is tasked with estimating the burden of cholera in the area. Which of the following is the simplest measure he can use?
explanation: The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure of estimating the burden of disease in the community. It signifies the proportion of all deaths that can be attributed to the disease. It is calculated as follows: Proportional mortality rate of a disease = (No. of deaths due to that disease in the year/ Total no. of deaths in the year) *100. Option A: Case fatality rate measures the risk of persons dying from a certain disease within a given time period. It measures the killing power of a disease. It is used to link mortality to morbidity. Option B: Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. It is not influenced by the duration of the disease. The use of incidence is generally restricted to acute diseases. Option C: Crude death rate is considered a fair indicator of the comparative health of the people. It is the rate of total deaths in a year compared to the mid-year population.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are researching the overall burden of COVID on a given population. Which of the following disability indicators is the best measure of this?
explanation: Disability adjusted life years (DALY) is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population. It is also the best measure of the effectiveness of interventions. DALY is calculated as - Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost to disability (YLD). It can measure both mortality and disability together. As DALY is affected by premature loss of life, conditions that affect younger individuals like road traffic accidents have a high DALY. In comparison to this, Alzheimer's disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age and so has a lower YLL.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a health utilisation rate?
options: Average length of stay in hospita
explanation: Bed disability days is not a utilisation rate. It is an event-type disability indicator. It is defined as the number of days a person spent in a hospital bed due to illness or injury. Health utilisation rate is defined as the number of people making use of the available health services to the total number of individuals in that population. Health utilisation rates include: Proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI) Proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery Percentage of population using family planning methods Bed occupancy rate Average length of stay in the hospita Bed turnover ratio
subject: PSM

question_text: As the medical superintendent of a hospital, you wish to optimise the utilization of health services. What bed turnover interval should you aim for?
explanation: For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, bed turnover interval must always be slightly positive. Bed turnover interval is defined as the time interval where a hospital bed is left unoccupied following a patient’s discharge till the next patient occupies it after admission.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the best indicator of availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health services?
explanation: Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care. It is a very sensitive indicator. Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000 It is also one of the best indicators of state failure. It is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live. Note: The best indicator of socio-economic development is the under-5 mortality rate.
subject: PSM

question_text: While reviewing a national health programme, you are asked to assess the cost-effectiveness of the interventions provided under it. Which indicator will you use to measure this?
explanation: QALY(Quality Adjusted Life Years) is used in assessing the cost-effectiveness (value of money) of a medical intervention. It is a measure of both the quality and quantity of life lived. It indicates the number of years of life that would be added by the intervention.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a socio-economic determinant of health?
explanation: Lifestyle is a behavioural and socio-cultural determinant of health. It is not a socio-economic determinant. Socio-economic determinants of health are the following: Economic status (per capita GNP) Education Occupation Political system Lifestyle is simply the way people live. It reflects our social values, attitudes, and activities. It is composed of: Cultural patterns (daily nutrition, superstitions) Behavioral patterns (personal hygiene, sedentary life) Lifelong personal habits (e.g. smoking, alcoholism) Lifestyle is learned by social interaction with parents, siblings, friends, school, and mass media. Our political system determines our health. It can help shape community health services with regards to resource allocation, manpower policy, choice of technology, and the degree to which these services are made available & accessible to all segments of the society. The percentage of GDP spent on health is an indicator of political commitment. WHO recommends at least 5% of GDP to be spent on health care. India spends about 2.1 % of its GDP on health(budget 2022-23).
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a socio-economic indicator of health?
explanation: Annual family income is not a socioeconomic indicator of health. Socio-economic indicators of health (mnemonic: H – FLAGGED): Housing (number of persons per room) Family size Literacy rate (especially female literacy rate) Availability of per capita calorie GNP per capita Growth rate of population UnEmployment leve Dependency ratio
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding positive health in today’s world?
options: It is dependent on social, economic, and cultural determinants
It is a mirage because of changing environment
It means that the body and mind are at peace
It includes provision of free health camps by the government
explanation: The provision of free health camps by the government is a concept of state medicine. Health does not merely mean the absence of disease or provision of diagnostic, curative, and preventive services. It is a state of physical, mental, and social well-being. The state of positive health is based on the idea of perfect functioning of the body and mind. According to this concept, health is: Biologically a state in which every cell and organ in the body is functioning at optimum capacity Psychologically a state in which the individual feels a sense of perfect well-being and mastery over his environment Socially a state in which the individual's capacities for participation in the social system are optima This concept is too idealistic and can never become a reality. Humans can never be so perfectly adapted to the environment because everything in our life is subject to change. As the goal of positive health is unattainable, a broader concept of improving the quality of life has emerged. This highlights that positive health depends on medical action and also on economic, cultural, and social factors in the community.
subject: PSM

question_text: As per the WHO, which of the following is not included in the standard of living?
explanation: Social security is a component of the level of living as per the United Nations and not standard of living. According to the WHO, the standard of living includes: Income and occupation Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition Level of provision of health, educational, and recreational services It depends on per capita GNP.

question_text: Which of the following are components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI)?
explanation: Infant mortality rate, literacy rate, and life expectancy at 1 year of age are the components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI).

explanation: Infant mortality rate (IMR) is not a component of HDI. It is a component of the physical quality of life index (PQLI). question_text: What are the minimum and maximum values established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI?
explanation: The minimum value established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI is 20 years and the maximum is 85 years. Adult literacy rate is not considered
Minimum and maximum values are based on global data

question_text:

explanation: Building social security is not included in the Ottawa charter for health promotion. The first international conference for health promotion was held in Ottawa on 21st Nov 1986. question_text: Which of the following is not a component of the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis?
explanation: Duration of illness is not a part of the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis. The epidemiological triad includes host, agent and environment: Host factors: Age, sex, religion, race, genetic profile, immune system Agent factors: Biological - bacteria, viruses Chemical - poisons, alcohol, smoke Physical - trauma, fire, radiation Nutrition - lack/excess Environmental factors: Temperature, humidity, altitude Water, milk, food Radiation, pollution, noise Crowding, housing, neighborhood Hence, a malnourished child (host), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (agent) and overcrowding (environment) form the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the most logical sequence?
explanation: Disease  Impairment  Disability  Handicap is the most logical sequence among the given options. Disease is a state of physiological/psychological dysfunction. Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function. Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment. Handicap is the disadvantage due to disability that limits fulfilment of a role that is normal.
subject: PSM

question_text: A salesman met with an unfortunate accident that led to him eventually losing his left foot. He has been unable to walk after this incident and so been rendered unemployed. Match the following examples with the corresponding events explaining the concept of disability.
explanation: The correctly matched events relating to the given example are as follows: The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function". E.g., loss of a foot. An initial impairment may cause a secondary impairment as well. The WHO defines disability as ''any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being". Because of impairment, the affected person may be unable to carry out certain activities and hence the person is considered disabled. According to the WHO, a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex, and social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages experienced by a person as a result of disability makes them handicapped. Event Example Disease/Disord er Accident Impairment Loss of fo ot Disability Cannot W alk Handicap Unemploy ed
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is most appropriate about the web of disease causation?
options: It implies that individual factors in the web have equal weightage
It implies that all the chains of causation must be controlled to prevent disease
It is mostly applicable for acute and rare diseases
It suggests ways of interrupting the disease occurrence
explanation: The web of causation for a disease suggests a number of ways to interrupt the disease occurrence/progression. This model was suggested by MacMahon and Pugh in their book ‘Epidemiologic Principles and Methods’. Web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited in the study of chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed. Sometimes removal of one significant link is sufficient to control the disease. In a multifactorial event, individual factors are by no means of equal weightage. The importance of each factor is expressed in terms of relative risk.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding the pathogenesis period of a disease?
options: Recovery is seen in this period
Entry of causative agent is seen
explanation: Primary prevention is not possible in the pathogenesis period of a disease. It can only be done in the period of pre-pathogenesis. The two phases in the natural history of a disease include: Period of pre-pathogenesis: It is before the onset of disease in humans. The disease agent has not entered the host, but the factors favouring the disease already exist. Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period. Period of pathogenesis: It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death or disability. Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period. It isn't always characterised by the presence of disease symptoms as it also includes subclinical cases.
subject: PSM

question_text: In the iceberg phenomenon of disease, which of the following does not represent the submerged portion of the iceberg?
explanation: Epidemiologically, the iceberg phenomenon of disease, diagnosed cases are represented by the floating tip of the iceberg. The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The water surface is the line of demarcation between the apparent and inapparent infections. The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, latent, and undiagnosed cases. Screening is done to identify these cases. The iceberg phenomenon of disease is depicted in the image below.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases shows the iceberg phenomenon?
explanation: Rubella shows the iceberg phenomenon of disease. The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles. Iceberg phenomenon is shown by: Polio Influenza Rubella Mumps Japanese Encephalitis Diphtheria Hepatitis A and B Tuberculosis Diabetes Malnutrition Hypertension Note: If a disease has more number of subclinical infections, it shows the iceberg phenomenon of disease depicted in the image below.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the term used to describe the interruption in the transmission of a disease?
explanation: Interruption in the transmission of a disease is called elimination. It is a step towards eradication. Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required. Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required. Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health. Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease.
subject: PSM

question_text: Among the following options, which aids the most in disease elimination?
explanation: Herd immunity aids the most in disease elimination. Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization, goes a long way in helping the elimination of diseases. When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease. The purpose of isolation is to protect the community by preventing the transfer of infection from the reservoir to the possible susceptible hosts. Quarantine refers to restrictions on the healthy contacts of an infectious disease.
subject: PSM

question_text: While collecting surveillance data for disease X, you find that the incidence of the disease is zero in your region. Which of the following statements best describes this scenario?
options: Disease is eliminated from the region.
Disease is well controlled in the region.
Disease is eradicated from the region.
Disease shows iceberg phenomenon in the region.
explanation: In the given scenario, as the disease has zero incidence, we can say the disease has been eliminated from the region. Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required. Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required. Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease. The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, latent, and undiagnosed cases. The clinical or diagnosed cases are represented by the floating tip of the iceberg and not the submerged portion. As disease incidence is zero here, there are no cases to form the iceberg.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a silent epidemic?
explanation: Alzheimer’s disease is referred to as the silent epidemic of the century. Nearly 50 million people globally are living with this disease. Since it strikes so often, so arbitrarily, and with such little warning, many have dubbed it the silent epidemic.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status of a population called?
explanation: The analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status or environment of a population is called monitoring. Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health. Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases and thereby supplementing the notified cases. Systematic reviews involve a detailed plan with the goal of reducing bias by identifying, appraising, and synthesizing all relevant studies on a particular topic.
subject: PSM

question_text: In which of the following does surveillance of disease not have a direct role?
options: Data on new and changing trends
explanation: Surveillance of a disease does not have a direct role in breaking the chain of transmission. Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health. It helps in health planning and provides information about public health disasters including data on new and changing trends of disease. Surveillance requires professional analysis and sophisticated judgment of data, leading to recommendations for control activities.
subject: PSM

question_text: Measures in sentinel surveillance do not aim at identifying:
explanation: Sentinel surveillance does not include identifying cases free of disability. Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases, in addition to the already existing and new cases. It is used for supplementing routine notifications.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is public health surveillance preferentially aimed at?
explanation: Public health surveillance is preferentially aimed at health planning. Public health surveillance provides important feedback on the health status of the population, about planning control and prevention activities, and also for public health disasters.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is included under primordial prevention of coronary artery disease?
explanation: Adoption of a healthy lifestyle from childhood would fall under the category of primordial prevention of coronary artery disease. Primordial prevention is preventing the emergence of risk factors among population groups in which these risk factors have not yet appeared. Most adult health problems (obesity, hypertension) have their early origins in childhood. It is in childhood that lifestyles are formed i.e. eating patterns, physical exercise, smoking, etc. In primordial prevention, efforts are made to discourage children from adopting harmful lifestyles. These lifestyle changes when made by adults are known as primary prevention.
subject: PSM

question_text: What type of prevention is the prescriptive screening of a disease?
explanation: Prescriptive screening of a disease is an example of secondary prevention. Prescriptive screening of disease can lead to early diagnosis of disease. By early diagnosis, intervention can be made to prevent disability. Hence, it comes under secondary prevention.
subject: PSM

question_text: What form of prevention is prospective screening?
explanation: Prospective screening is a type of primary prevention. Prospective screening is done on healthy individuals to screen for disease. It is done prior to the onset of the disease. E.g., screening donated blood for HIV before it is transfused. This type of prevention reduces the incidence of disease. Note: Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are screened for their own benefits. It is an early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. E.g., neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
subject: PSM

question_text: You advise a reproductive age woman to vaccinate against HPV. What is this type of prevention called?
explanation: The given scenario of immunisation is an example of primary prevention. Primary prevention is an action taken before the onset of disease. This reduces the possibility of disease occurrence. Hence, immunization is a form of primary prevention, through specific protection. Examples of primary prevention include immunization, sanitation, solid and liquid waste management etc.
subject: PSM

question_text: Who among the following is not a target for primary prevention?
explanation: Asymptomatic patients are the target population for secondary prevention but not for primary prevention. Primary prevention is implemented before the onset of the disease. Hence, all patients including asymptomatic ones are not included in the target group.
subject: PSM

question_text: As a part of the iodine deficiency control programme, you advocate the usage of iodized salt in hilly areas. What is this type of prevention an example of?
explanation: The usage of iodized salt in iodine-deficient areas like in hilly regions is an example of primary prevention as it provides specific protection.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are performing a routine pap smear on a 30-year-old woman in the gynecology OPD. What level of prevention does this fall under?
explanation: Pap smear is a screening test for carcinoma cervix and is an example of secondary prevention. Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment are the components of secondary prevention. Some of the examples of secondary prevention are as follows: Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer Mammography for early detection of breast cancer Colonoscopies for early detection of colon cancer Blood Pressure Screening Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures from a state of health.
subject: PSM

question_text: What mode of prevention is disability prevention by appropriate treatment an example of?
explanation: Disability prevention by appropriate treatment is an example of secondary prevention. This is because disability has not occurred yet so correct treatment can stop it from developing. After the disability has set in, prevention of progression of disability from transitioning into a handicap is tertiary prevention. It is also called disability limitation.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is an example of disability limitation?
options: Starting a patient on anti-tuberculous therapy
explanation: Prescribing spectacles for refractive error is an example of disability limitation which is a component of tertiary prevention. This mode of intervention is applicable when the patient presents late in the pathogenesis phase. The objective of this intervention is to prevent or halt the transition of the disease process from impairment to handicap. Option B: Starting a patient on anti-tuberculous therapy is secondary prevention as it is a part of treatment. Option C: Abstinence from smoking is a modification of the risk factor. Hence it is an example of primary prevention. Option D: Early fixation of fractures will prevent disability. Hence, it is an example of secondary prevention.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which among the following diseases was eliminated in India in 2015?
explanation: Maternal and neonatal tetanus was eliminated from India in 2015, as certified by the WHO. Important years for India (declared disease-free): Infective trachoma - 2017 Yaws - 2016 Maternal & neonatal tetanus - 2015 Polio - 2014 Guinea worm disease (dracunculiasis) - 2000 Worldwide eradication: Type-2 wild poliovirus - 2015 Type-3 wild poliovirus- 201š Smallpox - 1š›0
subject: PSM

question_text:
Which of the following statements is false about ICD- 11?
It includes a new chapter on traditional medicine
options: Gender incongruence is now listed as part of mental health
The codes relating to antimicrobial resistance are more closely in line with the Globa Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System
It has come into full effect from January 2022
explanation: The new ICD-11 has a new chapter on sexual health that contains gender incongruence, which was previously listed under mental health conditions in the ICD-10. The ICD 11 was released by the WHO in June 201› and was presented at the World Health Assembly in May 201š for adoption by the Member States. It has come into effect from 1 January 2022. Its designations for antibiotic resistance align with the Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS). It is given by the WHO and is revised every 10 years. New chapters added in ICD-11 are: Traditional medicine Sexual health: Gender incongruence has been moved from mental health to sexual health. Gaming disorder has been added under Addictive disorders. Immune system disorders, which will enable the better study of allergies. It has more detail on cancer, specifically different types of skin cancer, as well as on heart health and weight disorders compared to ICD-10. Principles of Epidemiology
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not included in the format of the death certificate recommended by the WHO?
options: Other significant conditions contributing to death
Age of person at the time of death
explanation: Age at the time of death is not included in the WHO format for a death certificate.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are filling the death certificate of a patient who died from rupture of the myocardium following an acute myocardial infarction. This was because of thrombosis in the coronary artery due to longstanding atherosclerosis. What will you record in line I (c) of the death certificate?
explanation: Coronary artery thrombosis is to be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate as one of the antecedent causes in the order of the events that took place. The flow of events in this patient is as follows: As per the recommendations of Forty-Third World Health Assembly 1990, an additional line (d) was added below (c) in part I of the death certificate, as approved by the WHO. Part II will only be filled up with a significant condition contributing to the death but not related to the disease or condition causing it.
subject: PSM

question_text: An HIV positive patient was suffering from multi-drug resistant tuberculosis. He died of respiratory failure due to lobar pneumonia. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate?
explanation: Lobar pneumonia is appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate. Line I (a) consists of the immediate cause of death such as the disease/condition. Immediate cause is the immediate/terminal event leading to death In this patient: I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Lobar pneumonia I(b) - Antecedent cause: MDR tuberculosis. II- HIV Respiratory failure is a mode of dying in this patient. It is not the cause of death. Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are just signs of death. Simply put, respiratory failure is 'how he died' whereas lobar pneumonia is 'why he died'. Therefore, lobar pneumonia (why he died) is the cause of the death.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a morbidity indicator?
explanation: Years of potential life lost is not a morbidity indicator. It is a mortality indicator. It is the years of potential life lost through premature death. Notification rates, spells of sickness and incidence are examples of morbidity indicators.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements about rate is false?
options: It measures the occurrence of an event in a population.
It has no specification of time.
It's numerator is mostly part of the denominator.
explanation: Rate is the measurement of the occurrence of a particular event in a given time. Hence, rates have a specification in time. Examples include crude death rate, incidence rate etc.
subject: PSM

question_text: To calculate the crude death rate of a country, at what time of the year is the population assessed?
explanation: The crude death rate is a mortality indicator, which uses the mid-year population as its denominator. The mid-year population is always attributed as the population on 1st July of any year. Hence for calculating the crude death rate, the population is assessed on the 1st of July.
subject: PSM

question_text: For which of the following purposes is age-specific death rates not used?
options: Identifying specific age groups at risk
Comparison for different causes within the same population
Comparison between different sexes in relation to accidents
Comparison between different age groups in relation to accidents
explanation: Sex-specific death rates are used for the comparison between sexes and not age-specific death rates. Age-specific death rates are used for: Comparison for different causes within the same population. Comparison between different age groups in relation to a particular event. Identifying specific age groups at risk.
subject: PSM

question_text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
explanation: Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease. Note: Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its calculation.
subject: PSM

question_text: Case fatality rate is .
options: ‹illing power of a disease in time
‹illing power of a disease with no time interva
explanation: Case fatality rate reflects the killing power of a disease with no specific time interval.
subject: PSM

question_text: A village has a population of 30,000 people. 500 of them contracted a disease X, out of which 75 died. What is the case fatality rate?
explanation: Case fatality rate is given by the formula: The total number of cases of disease X= 500 The total number of deaths= 75 Hence the case fatality rate= 75/500 x 100 = 15%
subject: PSM

question_text: In a village of 5000 people, an outbreak of cholera led to 200 cases with 50 deaths. What is the case fatality rate?
explanation: The case fatality rate is 25%. Case fatality rate: (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100 : 50/200 * 100 = 25%
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the simplest measure of the burden of a disease in a community?
explanation: The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure to estimate the burden of a disease in a community. It is commonly used for broad disease groups and when population data is not available.It is of limited value in making comparisons between populations and in identifying risk groups.
subject: PSM

question_text: Among the following, which measurement can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy?
explanation: The survival rate can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy. It is used as a method of describing prognosis and is widely employed in cancer studies. The survival rate is given by the following formula.
subject: PSM

question_text: Standardisation was done before comparing the mortality rates of two countries. What is the rationale behind this?
options: Due to difference in number of deaths.
Due to difference in age distribution.
Due to difference in the population density.
Due to difference in cause of death.
explanation: While comparing the mortality rates of two countries, the standardization of rates is done due to differences in age distribution. The two types of standardisation include direct and indirect. In both methods, a standard population is chosen where the numbers in each age and sex group are known and its choice is arbitrary. The commonly used standard populations are the Segi world population and the European standard population.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the standardized mortality ratio?
options: It is a form of direct standardization.
Observed deaths and expected deaths are part of its formula.
It can be used if the event of interest is occurrence of disease.
explanation: Standardized mortality ratio is a form of indirect standardization.
subject: PSM

question_text: A party was attended by 110 people out of which, 40 did not eat fruit salad. Among the rest of those who ate fruit salad, 55 developed food poisoning. What is the attack rate?
explanation: The attack rate is calculated by the formula: In this scenario, the number of new cases is 55 and the total number of those at risk is 70 as they ate the fruit salad. Therefore attack rate = 55/70 X 100 = 7‘.6%. Attack rate is an incidence rate. It is used only when the population is exposed to risk for a limited period.
subject: PSM

question_text: Out of a family of 4 members, one of them developed COVID-19 infection. Four days later, 2 other members developed the same. What is the secondary attack rate?
explanation: Secondary attack rate is calculated by the following: In this scenario, there is one primary case. The total exposed contacts are the other 3 members of the family. The number of persons developing the disease is 2. So, secondary attack rate = 2/3 x 100 = 66%. Note: The primary case is excluded from both the numerator and denominator.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following study designs would you prefer for calculating the incidence of a disease?
explanation: The study designs which can be used to calculate incidence are cohort studies and longitudinal studies.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements about incidence are true?
explanation: Incidence is not affected by the duration of the disease. Analysis of incidence rates may provide useful insights into the effectiveness of the health services provided. Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. Prevalence is more than incidence as it is the product of incidence and duration. Incidence is a type of rate and not a proportion.
subject: PSM

question_text: A medical officer noticed that there were 300 new cases of cholera in an area in a year. The total population in that area is 30,000. What is the incidence of cholera?
explanation: The incidence of cholera is 10 per 1000. Incidence is given by the formula: In this scenario number of new cases = 300 Total population = 30,000 Hence the incidence rate = (300/30,000) × 1000 = 10 Therefore it is 10 per 1000 per year.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a good indicator of efficacy of health programs?
explanation: Incidence is a good indicator of the efficacy of health services and programs.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false with regard to prevalence?
options: It is a product of incidence and duration.
It can be determined by a cross-sectional study.
It is an example of rate.
It is point prevalence unless specified.
explanation: Prevalence is a proportion, not a rate. Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies. Types of prevalence: Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
subject: PSM

question_text: The incidence of a disease is 4 per 1000 of the population with an average duration of 2 years. What is the prevalence?
explanation: The prevelance in the given situation is ‘/1000 population. Prevalence is given by the formula : Prevalance = Incidence x Mean Duration Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = ‘/1000 population
subject: PSM

question_text: A village has a total population of 100,000 with an under-16 population at 3%. The prevalence of goitre in the under-16 population is (0.3/100). What is the total number of under-16 population affected by goitre?
explanation: The total number of persons in the under-16 with goitre is 9. Number of total under-16 population = 3% of 100,000 = 3000. Thus, total number of goitre patients who are under-16 with the prevalence at the given value = 3000*0.3/100= 9
subject: PSM

question_text: In a population of 5000, new cases of TB are 500 and old cases are 50. What is the prevalence of TB in this case?
explanation: Prevalence is given by the formula: In the given scenario total no.of cases :50(old)+ 500(new) =550. Hence prevalence = (550/5000) x 100 = 11%
subject: PSM

question_text: In a village having a population of 5000, a diagnostic test for a particular disease showed the following results. What is the prevalence of the disease?
explanation: Prevalence is given by the formula: In this scenario, the number of cases: 1000+500 = 1500. Total population: 5000 Prevalence= 1500/5000 × 100 = 30%.
subject: PSM

question_text:
A randomized control trial showed an effective treatment against an infectious disease. It was then incorporated by the health system. Which of the following is subsequently expected to
happen?
explanation: A new effective treatment for infectious disease would reduce the duration of the disease, thereby reducing prevalence. Note: Both prevalence and incidence decrease but prevalence is the first to show a change in pattern. Hence, ‘prevalence decreases’ is the better answer.
subject: PSM

question_text: There was an outbreak of hepatitis A infection in your town. Proper prevention strategies were enforced. What is expected to happen at first to the number of cases of hepatitis A?
explanation: In the given scenario, prevention of hepatitis A would lead to decrease in incidence at first. Prevention of an acute disease would prevent new cases, thus first decreasing incidence.
subject: PSM

question_text: A new drug was approved for the treatment of prostate cancer. It has been shown to prevent early deaths but not cure the cancer. What is expected to happen to the cases of prostate cancer over a period of time?
options: Increase in incidence, no change in prevalence
Decrease in incidence, increase in prevalence
Increase in incidence, decrease in prevalence
Increase in prevalence, no change in incidence
explanation: A new drug that prevents death yet does not cure the disease will cause an increase in prevalence but the incidence remains the same. In the given scenario, the drug reduces early deaths but does not cure prostate cancer. Hence, there is a paradoxical increase in the prevalence while the incidence remains the same. Prevalence depends on two factors, the incidence and duration of illness. If the population is stable and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as: P = I X D (I - Incidence and D - Mean duration) This equation shows longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence. Note: In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence. If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases. If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxica increase in prevalence.
subject: PSM

question_text: Cross product ratio can be arrived from:
explanation: Cross product ratio (Odds ratio) can be obtained from the case-control study.
subject: PSM

question_text:
A person wants to study about the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, so he collects data about people diseased with lung cancer from government hospitals and the number of cigarette packets sold at the same time period. Which type of study is this?
Cross sectiona
explanation: The type of study described is an ecological study as the unit of study is the population. The number of cigarette packets sold at the same time is data about the population. Option A: The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is an individual. Option C: There is no experiment done here. Hence, it is not experimental study. Option D: Quasi-experiments are nonrandomized, pre-post intervention studies done when it is not feasible or ethical to conduct a randomized controlled trial. The unit of study is therefore patients or individuals and not population. Descriptive Epidemiology
subject: PSM

question_text: A researcher is planning to study the etiology of certain painful idiopathic peripheral neuropathies. Which of the following study methods shall he choose?
explanation: Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology.
subject: PSM

question_text: The preliminary observations made by Burkitt in Africa eventually found that the Epstein-Barr Virus is an etiological factor for Burkitt lymphoma. What is this study an example of?
explanation: The given scenario is an example of a descriptive study. Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology. These studies also led to the discovery of prions as the etiological agents of chronic degenerative neurological disorders (Kuru) in humans. This is also an example of a descriptive study. Types of epidemiological studies: Observational studies - allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene. Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population. Analytical studies - go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables. Ecological studies Cross-sectional studies Case-control studies Cohort studies Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other sciences. Randomized controlled trials Field trials Community trials
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following are included in descriptive epidemiology?
explanation: Descriptive epidemiology involves describing the disease in terms of time, place, and person distribution.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following best describes the term hypothesis?
explanation: An epidemiological hypothesis is a supposition or variable. It is arrived at from observation and needs to be tested. Descriptive studies primarily focus on the formulation of a hypothesis. Analytical studies which include study designs like case-control and cohort are used to test the formulated hypothesis. The hypothesis can subsequently be rejected or accepted. Experimental studies involve an intervention to provide scientific proof for etiological risk factors of diseases and to measure the efficiency of health services.
subject: PSM

question_text: The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is planning to study the natural history of COVID-19. Which of the following studies can be used?
explanation: Longitudinal studies are useful to study the natural history of a disease. It is also used to identify risk factors, and to find the incidence rate. In longitudinal studies, observations are repeated in the same population over a prolonged period of time by follow-up examinations. Their disadvantage is that they are difficult to organize and take a very long time.
subject: PSM

question_text: What are prevalence studies also known as?
explanation: Cross-sectional studies help in obtaining the prevalence of a disease. Hence, they are also known as prevalence studies. Cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is examined once at one point in time. It is more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute ones. They do not provide information on the natural history of disease or incidence and also do not establish the time sequence.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements about point source epidemic is false?
options: Clustering of cases occur within a short period of time
It occurs only due to an infectious agent
All cases usually develop within one incubation period
explanation: Point source epidemics are caused not only due to infectious agents but also by environmental pollution and contamination of food. Point source epidemics belong to the common source type of epidemics. Exposure to disease agents is brief so they are also called single exposure epidemics. All cases develop within one incubation period. In the epidemic curve, there is a sharp rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period. There are no secondary waves and these epidemics tend to be explosive.
subject: PSM

question_text: Identify the type of epidemic depicted from the following epidemic curve.
explanation: Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image. In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time. It occurs within one incubation period of the disease.
subject: PSM

question_text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
explanation: This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic. The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source. If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic. Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics: Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19. Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point source, multiple exposure outbreak. subject: PSM

question_text: The sales team of a corporate company presents to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting and loose stools. They give a history of having food from a nearby bakery three hours ago. What is this an example of?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of food poisoning. It is a type of common-source (point-source), single exposure epidemic.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is an example of disease following a seasonal trend?
options: Occurrence of rubella every 6-9 years in the pre-vaccination era
Occurrence of influenza pandemic every 7-10 years
Occurrence of bacterial gastroenteritis in summer
Increase in the occurrence of diabetes in developed countries
explanation: Occurrence of bacterial gastroenteritis in summer is an example of a disease following seasonal trend. Seasonal trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It refers to the occurrence of a disease in seasonal variation influenced by environmental conditions like climate, rainfall, life cycle of vectors, heat, etc. Examples are: Measles and varicella in early spring Bacterial gastroenteritis in summer Heatstroke in summer Dengue in July-November Respiratory infections in winter.
subject: PSM

question_text: The influenza pandemic is anticipated to occur every 7-10 years due to the antigenic variation of the virus. What is this an example of?
explanation: The influenza pandemic occuring every 7–10 years due to antigenic variations of the virus is an example of a disease showing cyclical trend. Diseases occurring in cycles spread over a short period of time show cyclical trends of time distribution. Cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. Examples include: Measles: every 2-3 years in the pre-vaccination era. Rubella: 6-9 years in the pre-vaccination era. Non-infectious conditions can also show cyclical trends.
subject: PSM

question_text: How often did the cyclical trends of measles occured in the pre-vaccination era?
explanation: In the pre-vaccination era, the cyclical trends of measles occurred every 2-3 years, while that of rubella occurred every 6-9 years.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is known as the change in the occurrence of a disease over very long periods of time?
explanation: A secular trend refers to the changes in the occurrence of a disease over long periods of time (decade). Usually, disease distributions tend to move in one particular direction over a period of time. Examples: Decrease in diseases like polio, tuberculosis, and typhoid fever, but increase in diabetes and coronary artery disease in developed countries.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following cannot be depicted by the image given below?
options: Rural - urban distributions of a disease
explanation: The given image is of a spot map. Spot maps are not used to depict rural-urban distributions of a disease. They help to understand the local distributions of a disease. They are also called shaded maps. This method was used by John Snow to investigate the epidemic of cholera in London in 1854. They depict areas of high or low frequency, the boundaries, and patterns of disease distribution.
subject: PSM

question_text: What are migration studies used to evaluate?
options: Socio-demographic reasons for migration of a population
Prevalence of diseases in a population
Environmental and genetic factors of a disease in a population
Incidence of disease in the immigrant population
explanation: Migration studies are used to evaluate the role of genetic and environmental factors of a disease in a population. The two methods used are: Comparing disease and death rates of migrants with kin who stayed at home Comparing disease and death rates of migrants with the local population of the host country Limitations of these studies: Non-randomization of these groups Environmental factors may act only up to a certain age Not useful for diseases with long incubation periods
subject: PSM

question_text:
What does bimodality in person distribution refer to?
Description of two etiological hypotheses of a disease in one person
options: Evaluation of two different environmental factors of a person in disease causation
Two separate peaks in the age incidence curve of a disease
Equal incidence of a disease in male and female population
explanation: Bimodality refers to the occurence two separate peaks in the age incidence curve of a disease. Example: Hodgkin's lymphoma shows a bimodal curve with peaks at 15–20 years and 70–80 years. The image below shows bimodality in the age incidence curve: Analytical Epidemiology
subject: PSM

question_text: You are conducting a cohort study in a group of headload workers to identify the risk factors for developing low back pain in future. This type of study falls under which of the following?
explanation: Cohort studies fall under non-experimental (observational) analytical studies. Classification of epidemiological studies: Observational studies: allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene. It is further classified into: Descriptive studies: limited to describing the occurrence of a disease in a population. Analytical studies: go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables. It includes: Ecological studies Cross-sectional studies Case-control studies Cohort studies Experimental studies or interventional studies: it involves an active attempt to change a disease eterminant or the progress of a disease, and is similar in design to experiments in other sciences. Randomized controlled trials Field trials Community trials
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the unit of observation in ecological studies?
explanation: In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population or community. Type of study Unit Ecological/ Correlational Population Cross-sectional/ Prevalence Individual Case-control/ Case reference Individual Cohort/ Follow up Individual Randomised Controlled Tria ls Patients Field Trial Healthy peo ple Type of study Unit Type of study Unit Community trial Community
subject: PSM

question_text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
explanation: The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred. It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference. Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc. Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.
subject: PSM

question_text: A study was conducted among a group of 500 patients with lung cancer and another group of 300 people chosen from the general population. Both the groups were questioned about their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
explanation: This is a case-control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people from the general population constitute the controls. The study is done from effect (lung cancer) to cause (smoking).
subject: PSM

question_text: A case-control study was conducted to evaluate the association between lifestyle risk factors and the prevalence of dyslipidemia. Which of the following is not an advantage of this type of study?
explanation: Incidence cannot be calculated from case-control studies. Incidence can be calculated from cohort studies, also known as longitudinal studies.
subject: PSM

question_text: A case-control study was conducted to see if symptoms of upper gastrointestinal dysfunction occurred more frequently in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the following cannot be used as controls in this study?
explanation: Siblings cannot be used as controls while studying genetic conditions because the outcome would be distorted due to their similarities. Controls in a case-control study: Usually disease-free Can be up to 4 times the number of cases in small studies In large studies, a 1:1 ratio of cases and controls can be sought Sources: general population, hospitals, relatives (spouses and siblings), neighbors, or colleagues Although, siblings cannot be used as controls for studies on genetic conditions
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
explanation: Hawthorne bias is not seen in case-control studies. This bias occurs when the subjects change their attitude/ actions while under observation. This distorts the results of the cohort or experimental studies. The bias that are seen in the case-control study are: Confounding Recall bias Selection bias Berkesonian bias Interviewer's bias
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not true about random errors?
options: Systematic errors are different from random errors
explanation: Random errors are not causes of bias. Random error arises when a value of the sample measurement diverges, due to chance alone, from that of the true population value. They can never be completely eliminated. Sources of random errors are individual biological variations, sampling errors, and measurement errors. Systematic errors are also called biases. They are different from random errors.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following factors in a study will cause Berkesonian bias?
options: Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects
Different rates of hospital admission of different diseases
Researcher's belief in the treatment changing the outcome of the study
Cases that are lost to follow-up
explanation: Berkesonian bias occurs due to the different rates of hospital admission of people with different diseases. It is a type of selection bias termed after Joseph Berkeson who described it.
subject: PSM

question_text: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
explanation: Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study. Recall bias is also called memory bias. It is widely seen in retrospective (case-control) studies as extensive history is taken from the participants.
subject: PSM

question_text: A study conducted in a group revealed that consumption of alcohol increases the risk of esophageal cancer, but it may be actually due to cigarette smoking. This happens due to:
explanation: In this scenario, cigarette smoking is related to both the outcome of esophageal cancer and consumption of alcohol. Thus, this is an example of a confounding factor. A confounding factor is defined as one which is associated with both exposure and outcome and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of alcohol in the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is considered as a confounding factor because: It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure). It is an independent risk factor for oesophageal cancer (outcome). In these conditions, the effects of alcohol consumption can be determined only if the influence of smoking is neutralized by matching.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding confounding factor?
options: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study
explanation: A confounding factor is a factor that is associated with both exposure and diseases and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. It can be reduced by matching. For example, if the study is that a sedentary lifestyle can lead to coronary artery diseases, then age can act as a confounding factor as it is individually linked to both sedentary lifestyle and coronary artery diseases.
subject: PSM

question_text: A researcher is planning to conduct a study to investigate the relationship between oral contraceptives and breast cancer. He wants to remove age as a confounding factor. Which of the following methods will not help him reduce this bias?
explanation: Deletion is not a method to reduce confounding. Methods to reduce confounding are: At the time of designing the study: Randomization Matching Restriction At the time of analysis: Stratification Statistical modelings like regression analysis, multivariate analysis, and the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.
subject: PSM

question_text: Matching is done for which of the following?
explanation: Matching helps only in removing the known confounding factors. Matching is the process by which controls are selected in a way that they are similar to cases in certain pertinent variables (e.g., age) that are known to influence the outcome of the disease. If not adequately matched for comparability, these variables could confound the results.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which among the following is not a type of matching?
explanation: There is no type of matching called collective matching. Types of matching: Group matching: It is also called frequency matching. It is done when a large stratum is used for study and a 1:1 ratio of cases and controls can be achieved. Individual matching: It is also called matching by pairs. It can be done when the study is small and more controls can be selected for one case.
subject: PSM

question_text: An epidemiologist determines to evaluate the strength of association between asbestos exposure and mesothelioma in a case-control study. Which of the following variables would he use for it?
explanation: Odds ratio (OR), also known as cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of association between risk factor (asbestos exposure) and outcome (mesothelioma) in case-control studies. A case-control study yields only odds ratio and not incidence or relative risk.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the odds ratio?
options: It is obtained from case-control studies
It is a measure of strength of association
explanation: An odds ratio (OR) of 1 indicates that there is no association or that the event is likely in both the groups.
subject: PSM

question_text: A case-control study was done among 500 lung cancer patients and 400 controls. The study groups had 400 and 50 smokers respectively. Calculate the odds ratio.
explanation: In the given scenario, the odds ratio (OR) is 28. The given data is represented as: Odds Ratio = ad/bc = (400 x 350) / (50 x 100) = (4 x 35)/5 = 4 x 7 = 28 Diseas e + Disease - Exposur e + 400 (a) 50 (b) Diseas Disease e + - Diseas Disease e + - Diseas Disease e + - Exposur e - 100 (c) 350 (d)
subject: PSM

question_text: A research scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study in a hospital to evaluate the association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following measures must she take, before starting the study?
options: Enrol all patients taking proton pump inhibitors
Enrol all patients on whom endoscopy was done
Exclude all patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease
Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori
explanation: All patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) must be excluded from a prospective cohort study, as the study progresses from cause to effect. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not true about cohort study?
options: It is always a prospective study design
Outcome is not present at the start of study
explanation: Although cohort studies are called prospective studies, there are subtypes of cohort studies that do not follow the prospective study design like historical (retrospective) cohort studies. Framingham Heart Study is one of the most famous long-term cardiovascular prospective cohort studies.
subject: PSM

question_text: Hawthorne effect is seen in which of the following studies?
explanation: Hawthorne effect is seen in cohort studies. It refers to the phenomenon when study subjects change or alter their behaviour during the course of the study, which results in different outcomes and underestimation of risks.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the ratio of the incidence of the disease in the exposed to that of the non-exposed?
explanation: The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
subject: PSM

question_text: Calculate the risk ratio when the incidence of the disease in exposed is 30 and that in non-exposed is 5.
explanation: In the given scenario, risk ratio or relative risk (RR) is 6. Here, the incidence of disease in the exposed is 30 and that in the non-exposed is 5. Thus, RR = 30/5 = 6.
subject: PSM

question_text: A cohort study was conducted among 10,000 smokers and 10,000 non-smokers. They were followed up over a period of 20 years. It was found that 100 of the smokers and 10 of the non-smokers developed oral squamous cell carcinoma. Calculate the relative risk.
explanation: The relative risk in the given scenario is 10. Here, the incidence in exposed is 0.01 (100/10000). Incidence in non-exposed is 0.001 (10/10000). Relative Risk = Incidence in exposed/ Incidence in non-exposed = 0.01/0.001 = 10.
subject: PSM

options: Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.1
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.˜
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 10

question_text: The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non exposed is given by which of the following variables?
explanation: The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed is given by attributable risk. Attributable risk is often expressed as a percentage.
subject: PSM

question_text: A study conducted among smokers shows that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking. Which of the following variables indicates this?
explanation: Attributable risk indicates to what extent the disease under study can be attributed to the exposure. Here, cigarette smoking is attributed to be the cause of 80% of lung cancers in smokers.
subject: PSM

question_text: A study found that the incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in non smokers. Calculate the attributable risk.
explanation: In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is 80%. Taking the incidence of disease in non-exposed as x, the incidence of disease in exposed would be 5x. Attributable risk (AR) would be given as [(5x - x)/5x] x 100 = 80%.
subject: PSM

question_text: In a population of ˜000 people, 2100 are alcoholics. 70 alcoholics and 23 non-alcoholics developed cirrhosis. What is the attributable risk?
explanation: In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is ˜0%. Number of people exposed (to alcohol) = 2100 Number of people not exposed (to alcohol) = 6˜00 Incidence of cirrhosis among exposed = 70/2100 (IExposed) Incidence of cirrhosis among non-exposed = 23/6˜00 (INon-exposed) Attributable risk (AR) = [ ( IExposed - INon-exposed) / IExposed ]*100 = [ (70/2100 - 23/6˜00) / (70/2100)] *100 = [ ˜ / 10 ] *100 = ˜0 Thus, the attributable risk (AR) is ˜0%.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the numerator in the formula for population-attributable risk?
options: Incidence among exposed minus incidence among non-expose
Incidence among non-exposed minus incidence among expose
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-expose
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among expose
explanation: Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-exposed is the numerator in population-attributable risk (PAR). Population attributable risk is obtained from cohort studies. It provides an estimate of the amount by which the disease could be reduced in that population if the suspected factor was eliminated or modified.
subject: PSM

question_text: A study was done in the Indian population to correlate the deaths due to myocardial infarction and dietary practices. What is this type of study known as?
explanation: This is an example of an ecological study. As the study was done in the Indian population, it can be inferred that population was taken as the unit of the study. The study was done to correlate the deaths and dietary practices, and hence ecological studies are also called correlational studies.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which among the following is the weakest study design to prove causation?
explanation: Ecological studies take a population as a unit. They provide the weakest evidence for causality because of extrapolation to individuals from regional data. Randomized control trials (RCTs) provide the strongest design amongst the options given. Case-control and cohort studies have moderate ability to provide evidence for causality.
subject: PSM

question_text:
What kind of bias is implied by assigning group characteristics to people which they may not possess as individuals?
Ecological fallacy
explanation: An ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals. Experimental Epidemiology
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following study designs is the best to prove causation?
explanation: Randomized controlled trials (RCT) are the strongest and best study design to prove causation. They are the gold standard of clinical research. Case-control and cohort studies have a moderate ability to provide evidence for causality. Ecological studies or correlational studies are considered as the weakest study design in this aspect. The difference between analytical studies and randomised controlled trials is that in the former there is no randomisation because it requires the participants to be divided into diseased and non-diseased. This can lead to a number of biases that are avoided in RCTs.
subject: PSM

question_text: In a clinical trial to evaluate a drug, randomisation was done before starting the trial. What is the purpose behind this?
