question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for routine immunization. According to the National Immunisation Schedule, which of the following would you administer?
explanation: At 5 years of age, the 2nd booster dose of DPT must be given along with the 9th (final) dose of vitamin A. 1st booster dose of DPT is given at 16 – 24 months of age. 1st dose of vitamin A is given at 9th month and the 2nd dose is given at 16 months followed by one dose every 6 months thereafter until the age of 5. Note: DPT booster + Vitamin A is a better answer than DPT booster + OPV because the 9th (final) dose of vitamin A must be given at 5 years but OPV at 5 years is an optional vaccine.
subject: PSM

question_text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the PHC for receiving the JE vaccine. The nurse cleans the injection site with a spirit swab and injects the live attenuated JE vaccine subcutaneously on the left upper arm. Which of the following statements is true regarding this scenario?
options: The procedure of administering the vaccine is wrong
The site of administering the JE vaccine is inappropriate
The JE vaccine cannot be administered under routine immunization in a PHC after 2 years of age
Only live attenuated JE vaccine is currently under use
explanation: The procedure of administration is wrong as it is not advisable to clean the injection site with a spirit swab because some of the live components of the vaccine are killed if they come in contact with spirit. The child is eligible to receive the Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine through routine immunization till 15 years of age. Live attenuated JE vaccine is administered in the left upper arm subcutaneously. JENVAC is a new inactivated vero cell culture derived JE vaccine produced by Bharath Biotech International limited in India. It is a Kolar strain-derived vaccine. The recommended dose is 0.5ml which is given intramuscularly at left anterolateral aspect of midthigh, 4 weeks apart starting from 1 year of age. Although a booster dose is recommended at a later period, the appropriate time for booster dose administration is not clear. JEEV is another inactivated vero cell culture derived vaccine from the SA-14-14-2 strain. The recommended dose is: 1-3 years: 2 doses of 0.25 ml on 0 and 28 days >3years, adolescents, and adults: 2 doses of 0.5ml on 0 and 28 days A booster dose of this vaccine is suggested to be given after 12 months of primary vaccination in non-endemic areas. The inactivated vaccines are currently under the recommendation of IAP. Under the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP), a live attenuated vaccine is given.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
explanation: Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month). The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are: TB Polio Hep B Diphtheria Pertussis Tetanus Measles The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are: Rotavirus diarrhoea Rubella (as MR vaccine) H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine) Pneumococcal meningitis Japanese Encephalitis The Intensified Mission Indradhanush 2.0: The government of India introduced IMI 2.0 to accelerate the vaccine drive and extend the coverage to children and pregnant women in identified districts and blocks from December 2019- March 2020. Note: Currently, the government has completed Intensified Mission Indradhanush 5.0: Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI 5.0), the flagship routine immunization campaign of the Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare concluded all 3 rounds in October 2023. This is the first campaign to be conducted across all the districts in the country and includes children up to 5 years of age (Previous campaigns included children up to 2 years of age). It also had a special focus on improvement of Measles and Rubella vaccination coverage.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are visiting a rural area for a vaccination drive conducted under the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. Which of the following vaccines would you not administer in this vaccination drive?
explanation: Typhoid vaccine is not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. The Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme has been introduced to ensure full immunization (>90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs) (updated from the 7 that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th-13th of each month). The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are: TB Polio Hep B Diphtheria Pertussis Tetanus Measles The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are: Rotavirus diarrhoea Rubella (as MR vaccine) H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine) Pneumococcal meningitis Japanese Encephalitis The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the National Deworming Programme?
options: It is conducted in the months of March and September
Free tablets are given to children up to the age of 15 years
It is carried out in schools and anganwadis
Age appropriate dose of tablet metronidazole is recommende
explanation: The National Deworming programme is carried out in schools and anganwadis. It is conducted twice a year, in the months of February and August, covering all the children from the age of 1 to 19 years. All the children are given age-appropriate dose of tablet albendazole. In the states of Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh, it is carried out only once a year (as the prevalence is <20% in these states).
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is true about the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke?
options: No separate centres for stroke, DM and cancer
Implementation in over 10 districts in 5 states
Subcentre has facility for diagnosis and treatment
explanation: District hospital has specialized facilities for the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS). The NPCDCS has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states. At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral are done. Note: The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke(NPCDCS) has been changed to the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases(NP-NCD) to include new diseases and new health initiatives. The new diseases included in the NP-NCD are: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease Chronic Kidney disease Asthma and Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ST elevation myocardial infarction
subject: PSM

question_text:
Which of the following is a false statement about the Indian Hypertension Control Initiative
(IHCI)?
options: The IHCI monitoring personnel includes cardiovascular health officers and senior treatment supervisors
Provision of real-time blood pressure monitoring for all patients via information systems
The IHCI provides 30-day medication for individuals registered for hypertension management
The target is a 90% reduction in the prevalence of hypertension by the year 2025
explanation: The false statement about the Indian Hypertension Control Initiative is a 90% reduction in the prevalence of hypertension by the year 2025. The IHCI is an initiative by the MoHFW, WHO, ICMR, and state governments to control hypertension in India. It has adopted the goal of “25 by 25” to reduce the prevalence of hypertension in India by 25% by 2025. The activities of IHCI are monitored by the cardiovascular health officers (CVHO's) at the state and district level and by the senior treatment supervisors (STS's) at the sub-district level. The IHCI has strengthened the prevention of hypertension by ensuring the provision of antihypertensive medications for 30 days to all patients registered under the IHCI. The 5 components of IHCI are: Use of standardized hypertension treatment protocols approved by national and global policies. Availability of recommended protocol drugs to provide a regular and uninterrupted supply of medications. Task-sharing and team-based care involving nurses, health workers, and ASHAs to improve treatment compliance. Patient-centered services provide easy access to BP monitoring at Health & wellness centers and PHCs. Information systems that provide real-time BP monitoring to improve patient follow-ups: Use of the “Simple App” in all IHCI states. *Note: Amlodipine, telmisartan, and chlorthalidone are the drugs of choice in the standardize treatment protocols of the IHCI.
subject: PSM

question_text: Under the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment, NGO eye hospitals are considered as:
explanation: NGO eye hospitals are considered secondary level centres under the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). Levels of eye care centres according to NPCBVI: Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centres, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, and link workers. Secondary level: District hospitals and NGO eye hospitals. Tertiary level: Regional institutes of ophthalmology and medical colleges. The goal of NPCBVI is to reduce the prevalence of blindness to 0.25% by 2025.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is used to measure the output of the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment?
options: Number of cases of refractory errors correcte
Number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration
Number of cases of childhood blindness detected and cure
Prevalence of blindness reduced by 0.5% per year
explanation: The measure of the output of the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment (NPCBVI) is indicated by the number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration. The most common cause of low vision in India is cataract (low vision is visual acuity <6/18- 6/60).
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases is not a part of the Vision 2020 programme in India?
explanation: Onchocerciasis is not a part of the Vision 2020 programme in India. It is a part of the Global Vision 2020 programme. question_text: A pregnant woman from a rural area registers under Janani Suraksha Yojana. Which of the following services would not be provided to her under this scheme?
options: Safe motherhood services under Vandematharam scheme
explanation: The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) does not provide STD counseling. Janani Suraksha Yojana is a safe motherhood intervention launched under National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women. The services provided by the JSY are: Cash is disbursed to the mother at the institution for having an institutional delivery. Safe motherhood services (IFA tablets, TT vaccination) under the Vandemataram scheme. Village health and nutrition day Maternal death review Pregnancy tracking: ASHA worker/Anganwadi Worker (AWW) or any other link worker help in monitoring antenatal check-ups, and post-delivery care. Safe abortion services: mifepristone followed by misoprostol and manual vacuum aspiration.
subject: PSM

question_text: Where and how often is the Village Health Nutrition Day conducted?
options: Once every two weeks in PHC
Once every two weeks in Anganwadi
explanation: Village Health Nutrition Day is conducted once a month in the Anganwadi centres in the village itself. The villagers interact with health workers and are provided with basic services and information about health care.
subject: PSM

question_text: A 20-day old baby is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go to the nearby hospital. Which national programme has provisions to benefit this woman to take her baby to the health facility?
explanation: The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from: home to the health facilities between facilities in case of a referral back home from the health facilities The provisions of JSSK include: Free transport Free treatment Free drugs and consumables Free diagnostics and diet Free and cashless delivery Free C-Section Free provision of bloo Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.
subject: PSM

question_text: The Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram was designed for which of the following demographic groups?
explanation: The Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) was designed to train health personnel in basic newborn care and resuscitation. The training is aimed to improve the delivery of excellent newborn care at every point and is usually done for 2 days.
subject: PSM

question_text: A 10-year-old girl has just started menstruating. Under which of the following national programmes, she will be provided with a pack of sanitary napkins by the ASHA worker in her village?
explanation: The girl will be provided with a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA worker through the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme under the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK). RKSK focuses on: Development of adolescent population (10-19 years). Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation (100mg Fe + 500 mcg Folic Acid) Menstrual hygiene: A pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA. It also includes enhancement of mental health and prevention of substance abuse and violence. Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana is a government-sponsored savings program for parents of girl children <10 years age. It helps parents to set aside money for their female child’s potential college and marriage expenses by opening an account at any post office branch or any commercial bank approved by the central government. Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) seeks to empower adolescent girls, so as to enable them to take charge of their lives. The objectives are to: improve the nutritional, health and development status of adolescent girls promote awareness of health, hygiene, nutrition and family care opportunities for learning life skills going back to school help them gain a better understanding of their social environment take initiatives to become productive members of society. Recent update: Department of Pharmaceuticals under Ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers has recently launched ‘Suvidha’ (100% Oxo-biodegradable Sanitary Napkin), under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) on World menstrual hygiene day. ‘Swachhta, Swasthya and Suvidha’ will be available for Rs. 1 per pad over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendras for the underprivileged women of India.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which among the following is not true about POSHAN Abhiyan?
options: It is a programme of the Ministry of Women and Child Development
The goals are to achieve improvement in neonatal mortality
Launched on the date of International Women's Day 2018
Targets to reduce low birth weight by 2% per annum
explanation: The goal of POSHAN Abhiyaan /National Nutrition Mission (NNM) is to achieve an improvement in the nutritional status during the next three years beginning 2017-18. It is a flagship programme of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD). Its target population include: children from 0-6 years adolescent girls pregnant women lactating mothers The logo is: The following image depicts the targets of this mission: Note: Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government scheme in India to provide Rs.500 per month for TB patients to buy food.

question_text: Which of the following is the objective of the Ujjawala Scheme?
options: Provide LPG connections to families below poverty line
Provide LED bulbs in every househol
explanation: The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation. The Ujjwala Yojana (note spelling without "a") is for providing 5 crores of free cooking LPG connections to all families below the poverty line till 2019. The Ujala Scheme (Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs and Appliances for All) is the largest domestic lighting project in the world, launched under the Ministry of Power. It aims at promoting the use of energy-efficient LED bulbs in every household in the country. INSPIRE strategy is a set of 7 evidence-based strategies introduced to select, implement, monitor, and evaluate effective policies, programs, and services to prevent and respond to violence against children.
subject: PSM

question_text: An ASHA worker is offering services under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in her village. All of the following services will be provided by her except:
options: Information, education, communication and public awareness
explanation: Water pollution is not managed under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was launched in 2014 with an aim to eradicate open-air defecation by the year 2019 through the construction of 12 million toilets. The two sub-missions of Swachh Bharat Abhiyan are Swachh Bharat Mission Gramin (SBM-G) and Swachh Bharat Mission Urban (SBM-U). Components of this mission include: Household toilets including improving unsanitary latrines Community toilets Public toilets Solid waste management Information, education, communication, and public awareness Capacity building and administrative & office expenses
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?
options: Government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year
The limit of the family size that is covered is up to 7 members
All pre-existing diseases of the individual are covere
It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization
explanation: There is no cap on family size or the age of the members. All the families listed under the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database are covered as per the defined criteria. The following are the benefits provided under this program: Health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year. All families listed in the SECC database, as per the defined criteria, will be covered. There is no cap on family size and age of members. Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals Both secondary and tertiary care hospitalization is covered. All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment. To control costs, the payments for treatment will be done on a package rate (to be defined by the Government in advance) basis. Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services. Logo:

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana?
options: Unemployment allowance is not given in case of closure of factory
Unemployment allowance is given in case of employment injury
Allowance is given at 50% of the daily wage for a maximum of 2 years
To qualify for the scheme, worker must have worked for more than 2 years
explanation: Unemployment allowance under Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana (RGSKY) is given at the rate of 50% of daily wage for a maximum of 2 years. RGSKY is a scheme of ESI that provides unemployment allowance to an insured person going out of employment involuntarily, on account of: closure of a factory or establishment retrenchment (laying off employees due to economic difficulty) permanent disability due to nonemployment injury Allowance and eligibility criteria of Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana (updated in 2019): The allowance is given at the rate of 50% of the daily wage for a maximum of 2 years. To qualify for the scheme the worker must have worked in that setup for >3 years. Note: Disability due to employment injury is covered under disablement benefits of ESI Act, 1948. Temporary disability: 90% of wages until disablement lasts. Permanent disability: 90% of wages as a life pension on the basis of loss of earning capacity. Dependants benefit: 90% of wage as monthly payment to the dependants of the decease person, in cases where death occurs due to employment injury or occupational hazards.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following does the Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refer to?
options: Initiative for providing free sanitary pads
Initiative to provide vaccination to under-5 children
Initiative for labour room quality improvement
Initiative to provide affordable healthcare to all
explanation: The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refers to the initiative for labour room quality improvement. There is enough evidence to support the fact that improving the quality of care in labour rooms, especially on the day of birth, is crucial to maternal and neonatal survival. Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care being provided to the pregnant mother in the labour room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth. This initiative is implemented in government medical colleges besides district hospitals, and high delivery load sub-district hospitals, and community health centres. It plans to conduct quality certification of labour rooms and also incentivize facilities achieving the targets outlined. The goal is to reduce preventable maternal and new-born mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in labour room and maternity OT, and ensure respectful maternity care.
subject: PSM

question_text: The image below shows the logo of which of the following national programmes?
explanation: The image shown is the new logo of the 360-degree holistic Family Planning Campaign. Logo of other options: "Beti bachao Beti padhao." India Newborn Action Plan (INAP) The logo of Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (JSSK)

question_text: What is the main objective of the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Jan-aushadhi Pariyojana?
options: Improve maternal and child health services
Make quality, generic medicines affordable to all
Enhance quality of life and increase employment for the differently able
Promote cleanliness and enhance quality of healthcare facilities in India
explanation: The Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Jan-aushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) carries the objective of making quality, generic medicines affordable for everyone, especially the lower socio-economic groups. BPPI (Bureau of Pharma PSUs of India), under the Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers, is the implementation agency for PMBJP. The mission of this programme includes creating awareness and demand for generic medicines through education and supply of such medications. Kayakalp programme is a national initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) under Swachh Bharat Abhiyan to promote cleanliness and enhance the quality of healthcare facilities in India.
subject: PSM

question_text: The Mid Day Meal Programme aims to supplement:
explanation: Under the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at least 1/2 of total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of total daily energy requirement of children in schools. The MDM scheme is also called School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme. Some other principles of the MDM are: The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home iets. The cost of meals should be reasonably low. The meal should be easy to cook in schools. Locally available foods must be used, for as far as possible. The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony. Note: In September 2021, the Mid-Day Meal Scheme was renamed PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the Vandematharam scheme?
options: Its aim is to provide safe motherhood services
An MBBS graduate or an obstetrician can volunteer
IFA tablets and TT injections are provided by District Medical Officers
explanation: The Vandematharam scheme does not include free treatment in private clinics. Vandematharam scheme is a voluntary scheme for providing safe motherhood services. It can be volunteered by an obstetrician, maternity home, nursing home, lady doctor or an MBBS graduate. IFA tablets, OCPs, and TT injections are provided by the respective District Medical Officers (DMOs) to the Vandematharam doctors or clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries. Cases needing special care and treatment can be referred to government hospitals.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a component of the scheme depicted by the logo given below?
explanation: National Health Protection Mission is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme. Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are: Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- these centres will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services an non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services. National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) provides health protection cover to poor an vulnerable families, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others. Beneficiary Level: The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year. All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members. Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens. Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals in times of need. Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics. All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment. Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services. Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment. Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following vaccines has not been introduced to the immunization programme in India?
explanation: Influenza vaccine (Flu shot) has not been introduced to the National Immunization Programme in India. The Influenza vaccine provides protection against viral flu caused by the influenza virus. Note: Bacterial Hemophilus influenzae type-b (Hib) vaccine is different from the viral influenza (Flu) vaccine. HiB is a part of the pentavalent vaccine.
subject: PSM

question_text: The POCSO Act is related to which of the following?
explanation: The POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act is related to child sexual abuse. POCSO Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines different forms of sexual abuse, including penetrative and non-penetrative assault, as well as sexual harassment and pornography. The Act deems a sexual assault to be "aggravated" under certain circumstances, such as when the abused child is mentally ill or when the abuse is committed by a person in a position of trust or authority vis-à-vis the child, like a family member, police officer, teacher, or doctor. People who traffic children for sexual purposes are also punishable under the provisions relating to abetment in the Act. The Act prescribes stringent punishment graded as per the gravity of the offence, with a maximum term of rigorous imprisonment for life and a fine.
subject: PSM

question_text: Mass drug administration is not done for which of the following conditions?
explanation: Mass drug administration is not done in case of vitamin A deficiency. Mass Drug Administration (MDA) is the administration of a drug to an entire concerned population irrespective of age and gender. For example, antimalarials are given as MDA in malaria-endemic island communities and in low-endemic non-island settings approaching elimination, where there is minimal risk of re-introduction of infection, good access to treatment, and implementation of vector control and surveillance. Vitamin A prophylaxis is given under National Immunization Schedule (NIS) only to children up to 5 years. It is given as mass prophylaxis and not as a drug for treatment. Vitamin A as a treatment is given only to a child with features of vitamin A deficiency and such doses are not instituted to everyone in the community. Therefore, it is not considered under MDA. On the other hand, MDA is done in scabies (ivermectin), worm infestation (albendazole), and filariasis (DEC + albendazole).
subject: PSM

question_text: Monetary benefit is measured in which of the following analyses?
explanation: The monetary benefit is measured in a cost-benefit analysis. In cost-benefit analysis, the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given programme is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programmes. The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field, as a result of a particular programme, cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. We generally express the benefit in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome. In cost-effective analysis, the benefit is expressed in terms of results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease). Input-output analysis: how much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time); and output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed. Network analysis: a network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective. question_text: As per NCEP- ATP III, which of the following is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome?
explanation: As per NCEP- ATP III, high LDL is not included in the definition criteria of metabolic syndrome. Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III). It includes: Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F) Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level  150 mg/dL Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively. Hypertension: blood pressure 130 mmHg systolic or  85 mmHg diastolic. Fasting plasma glucose level: 100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.
subject: PSM

question_text: In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to (per 1 lakh live births):
explanation: In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births. There are 17 global goals and 169 targets set for 2030 as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030.
subject: PSM

question_text: As per the new National Policy for Rare Diseases, financial support of up to Rs. 20 lakhs can be given to which group of rare diseases?
explanation: As per the new National Policy for Rare Diseases, a provision for financial support of up to Rs. 20 lakhs under the umbrella scheme of Rashtriya Arogya Nidhi is proposed for the treatment of rare diseases that require a one-time treatment (listed under Group 1 in the rare disease policy). National Policy for Rare Diseases is a comprehensive policy for the prevention and management of rare diseases. The policy lists rare diseases under 3 groups: Group 1: Disorders amenable to one-time curative treatment: Disorders amenable to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation eg: lysosomal storage disorders Disorders amenable to organ transplantation eg: glycogen storage disorders, urea cycle isorders, ADPKD, etc. Group 2: Diseases requiring long term/ lifelong treatment having a relatively lower cost of treatment: This group includes disorders managed with special dietary formulae/ hormone/ specific drugs. eg: phenylketonuria, osteogenesis imperfecta, etc. Group 3: Diseases for which definitive treatment is available but treatment is lifelong or expensive: This group includes diseases such as Pompe disease, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, etc. The objectives of the policy are: Lowering the high cost of treatment for rare diseases with an increased focus on indigenous research. Creating a national hospital-based registry of rare diseases. Early screening and prevention through primary and secondary health care infrastructure, an through counselling for the high-risk parents. Crowdfunding mechanism in which corporates and individuals will be encouraged to exten financial support.
subject: PSM

question_text:
You are a medical officer at a PHC. Which of the following would you advise for mass prophylaxis/ treatment for anemia?
FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12
Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose
Ferrous fumarate
explanation: Among the given options, FeSO4 + vitamin C + Folate + vitamin B12 may be considered for mass prophylaxis against anemia. Vit C enhances the absorption of iron from the stomach by acting as a reducing substance. Subclinical folate deficiency is seen in up to 30% of North Indian pregnant women. Moreover, it may be masked by widespread iron deficiency. It is, for this reason, iron and folate supplementation is carried out in national programmes. Clinical vitamin B12 deficiency is not commonly encountered, but subclinical cases might be seen in up to 30% of adults and children due to widespread restriction to consumption of vegetarian products only. Hence supplementing vitamin B12 is a good idea provided the cost factor is not an issue. Option B: Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose was marketed as being superior to iron sulfate in terms of efficacy, but it lacked any data to back up the evidence. Option C: Ferrous fumarate may be considered for the treatment of iron deficiency anemia with similar efficacy as that of ferrous sulfate. Option D: Injection iron sucrose or any parenteral form is not used as a first-line option. It is only indicated if the oral form is not tolerated. Demography I: Demographic Cycle, Annual Growth Rate and Age Pyramid
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a demographic process?
explanation: Morbidity is not a demographic process. Demography refers to the study of the population. Demographic processes include: Fertility Mortality Marriage Migration Social mobility These processes continuously bring about changes in the population size, composition, and distribution.
subject: PSM

question_text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the death rate start declining?
explanation: The death rate starts declining in stage 2 or the early expanding phase of the demographic cycle.
subject: PSM

question_text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the birth rate start declining?
explanation: The birth rate starts declining in stage 3 or the late expanding phase of the demographic cycle. India is currently in this stage of the demographic cycle. The year 1921 is called the year of the great divide in India. This is because, since 1921, the absolute number of people getting added to the population during each decade has been on the rise. This is the year in which India moved from stage 1 to stage 2 of the demographic cycle.
subject: PSM

question_text: A group of demographers studied the changes in the birth and death rates of two countries, A and B from the year 2001 to 2011. The collected data is given below. In which stages of the demographic cycle are countries A and B in respectively?
explanation: In the given scenario, country A is in stage 2 and country B is in stage 4 of the demographic cycle. According to the given data, in country A, the high birth rate has remained unchanged with a decline in the death rate. This will result in an exponential increase in the population. This means country A is in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle. In country B, the low birth rate and death rates have remained unchanged. Thus, the population will attain a plateau phase and remain stationary. This means country B is in the low stationary stage of the demographic cycle.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?
options: Birth rate falls below death rate
explanation: In stage 5 of the demographic cycle, the birth rate falls below the death rate. In this stage, the death rate attains a low stable rate while the birth rate keeps declining. Thus, the curve of the birth rate will cross the curve of the death rate in a graph of the demographic cycle and falls further below. The demographic gap is negative and the population is declining. So, this stage is known as the declining stage.
subject: PSM

question_text: While studying the birth and death rates of a country, a demographer found it to be in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle. Which of the following findings would lead him to such a conclusion?
options: Increased birth rate and decreased death rates
Decreased birth rate and increased death rates
Unchanged birth rate and decreased death rates
explanation: Early expanding stage (stage 2) of the demographic cycle is characterized by an unchanged birth rate and decreasing death rate.
subject: PSM

question_text: A researcher is studying the demographic cycle of various countries. In which stages of the cycle will she notice an increase and a decrease in the demographic gap respectively?
explanation: The demographic gap starts increasing in stage 2 and starts decreasing in stage 3. The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rate and death rate which develops when a country undergoes a demographic transition. In stage 2 of the demographic cycle, the death rate declines but the birth rate remains unchanged. Hence, the demographic gap increases and reaches a maximum by the end of stage 2. In stage 3, both the death rate and birth rate are declining so the demographic gap starts decreasing.
subject: PSM

question_text: At which stage of the demographic cycle will the demographic gap be maximum?
explanation: The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum in the early expanding phase of the demographic cycle.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the stage of demographic cycle marked by the red arrow?
explanation: The marked stage is the late expanding phase (stage 3) of the demographic cycle. A demographic gift or demographic dividend is seen in this stage. This refers to the presence of a higher number of economically productive individuals (young and middle-aged adults) in the population due to a higher birth rate in the previous demographic phase (phase 2). India is currently experiencing the demographic gift. The birth rate starts declining alongside a death rate that continues to fall in stage 3 causing a decline in the demographic gap. The death rate declines further and the birth rate falls in this stage.
subject: PSM

question_text: In which stage of the demographic cycle will the phenomenon of a demographic trap be maximally seen?
explanation: The phenomenon of a demographic trap is seen maximally in the early expanding stage (stage 2). This phenomenon refers to a period in which there is high fertility and birth rate and a declining death rate. The population grows exponentially in this stage and this growing population exceeds the national or regional carrying capacity. Countries in this stage are said to be caught in a demographic trap.
subject: PSM

question_text: While conducting a field study in a village, you found the birth and death rates of the population to be 42 and 31 respectively. What is the current annual growth rate of this population?
explanation: In the given scenario, the current annual growth rate is 1.1%. Here, the birth rate is 42 i.e 42 live births per 1000 population, and the death rate is 31 i.e 31 deaths per 1000 population. Current annual growth rate = crude birth rate – crude death rate. So, current annual growth rate = 42-31= 11 per 1000 population or 1.1%.
subject: PSM

question_text: The population of a country is 1 lakh in the year 2000 and its annual growth rate is 2%. By which year will the population of this country become 2 lakhs?
explanation: For the given country, its population would become 2 lakhs i.e, double the population from the year 2000, by the year 2035. As per the Malthusian growth model, when the annual growth rate is 1%, the population doubles in 70 years. Therefore, when the annual growth rate is 2%, the population will double in 35 years. The Malthusian growth model/ rule of 70: The growth rate of India is estimated at 1% as per 2020 UN data. Therefore, it falls in the rapidly growing phase of population growth. question_text: What was the population of India, as of 2021?
explanation: The population of India, as of 2021, was around 1.39 billion. This is as per UN 2021 data.
subject: PSM

question_text: According to the 2021 UN data, what is India's population growth rate?
explanation: According to UN data, India's population growth rate in 2021 was 1%. As per the last published SRS data of the Indian government, it was 1.2% in 2018. India's population is currently increasing at a rate of 16 million each year. It currently falls in the rapidly growing phase of population growth.
subject: PSM

question_text: You have been tasked with studying the age and sex structure of a population with high rates of female infanticide. Which of the following methods will you prefer to use?
explanation: The age and sex structure of a population may be best represented using a population pyramid. It is a histogram that shows the distribution of ages across a population. It is divided down the center between male and female members of the population.
subject: PSM

question_text:
What does the age pyramid of India look like?
Broad at base and narrow at apex
options: Broad at apex and narrow at base
Broad in the middle and narrow at base
explanation: The age pyramid of India is broad at the base and narrow at the top. This is typical of most developing nations. Demography II: Demographic indicators
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a vital statistic?
explanation: Sex ratio is not a vital statistic, it is a population statistic. Demographic indicators have been divided into 2 parts: Population statistics include - Population size Sex ratio Density Dependency ratio Vital statistics include - Birth rate Death rate Natural growth rate Life expectancy at birth Mortality rate Fertility rate
subject: PSM

question_text: While conducting a demographic study, you need to calculate the total dependency ratio of the study population. Which of the following will you include in the numerator while calculating this?
options: Population under 10 years and above 60 years
Population under 15 years and above 60 years
Population under 10 years and above 65 years
Population under 15 years and above 65 years
explanation: Population under 15 years and above 65 years are part of the numerator used to calculate the total dependency ratio. This is because this population is considered the dependant population. The dependant population includes children below 15 years of age and adults above 65 years of age. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 - 65 years. It is also called the societal dependency ratio. It can also be divided into the young-age and old-age dependency ratios. Note: As of mid-year 2020, the dependency ratio of India is 48.7%.
subject: PSM

question_text: While studying a community, the researcher found 30% of the population to be below 15 years of age, and 10% was over 65 years of age. What is the total dependency ratio of this population?
explanation: The total dependency ratio in this population is 66.6%. This can be calculated as follows. Here, the total population below 15 years of age is = 30% Total population above 65 years of age = 10% So, total population between 15-65 years of age = 100 - (30 + 10) = 60% Hence, dependency ratio in this population = 100* (30% + 10%)/60% = 66.6%
subject: PSM

question_text:
What is potential support ratio?
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per child below 15 years or less
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per older person aged 65 or more
options: Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged >65 and younger person aged
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per each older person aged > 60 and younger person aged
explanation: The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. It is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the major contributor to demographic burden?
explanation: Demographic burden refers to an increase in the total dependency ratio. It is mostly caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio. The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility. A decline in dependency ratio especially the young-age dependency ratio has been identified to be a key factor in the underlying rapid economic development. The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following determines the carrying capacity of a population?
explanation: The carrying capacity is the number of individuals of a population that can be supported for a period of time given the resources of that area. Thus, the carrying capacity is determined by the limiting resources of an area.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false about crude birth rate?
explanation: The numerator of crude birth rate only includes live births and does not include stillbirths. Crude birth rate = No. of live births during the year x 1000/ Estimated mid-year population
subject: PSM

question_text: As part of the national maternity benefit scheme, you have been tasked with conducting a study in a community of 5000 people. What is the expected number of pregnant women in this community if the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people?
explanation: The expected number of pregnant females in the given community would be 165. Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people i.e 30 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 30 pregnant females per 1000 population. Step 2: Since the total population is 5000, the total no of pregnant females = 5000 x 30/1000 = 150 Step 3: Since some pregnancies may not result in live births (abortions and stillbirths), a correction factor of 10% should be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies. Pregnancy wastage (i.e 10% of total live births) =10 x 150/100=15. Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live births + pregnancy wastage = 150+15=165.
subject: PSM

question_text: According to NFHS-5, what is the sex ratio in India?
explanation: According to the NFHS-5 (2019-21), the sex ratio in India is 1020 females per 1000 males. It has increased from the 2011 Census which had found a sex ratio of 940 females per 1000 males. The sex ratio at birth is 929 females per 1000 males.
subject: PSM

question_text: For a population of 10,000, what does a sex ratio of more than 1000 mean?
explanation: For a population of 10000, if the sex ratio is more than 1000, it means males are less than 5000 i.e., less than half the population. The sex ratio refers to the number of females per 1000 males. An ideal sex ratio would be 1000, indicating the population comprises an equal number of males and females. Sex ratio >1000 indicates that there are more females than males in a population. Sex ratio <1000 indicates that there are fewer females compared to males in the population.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the definition of the net reproduction rate?
options: No. of children that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of girls that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of female children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
explanation: Net reproduction rate (NRR) is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate. India is aiming for an NRR of 1 as it is equivalent to the two-child norm.
subject: PSM

question_text:
An epidemiologist would consider the growth of his study population to be inadequate if he found the NRR to be:
<1
explanation: If the NRR is less than 1, then the population growth of a community is said to be inadequate. Net reproduction rate (NRR) is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming age-specific fertility and mortality rates.
subject: PSM

question_text: What should the net reproductive rate of a population be to attain a 2 child norm?
explanation: The net reproductive rate (NRR) should be 1 to attain the 2 child norm.
subject: PSM

question_text: In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?
explanation: In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the denominator used in the formula for calculating the general fertility rate?
options: Total number of women in the population
Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age group
Total number of married women in the age group 15 – 45
explanation: The denominator used to calculate the general fertility rate is mid-year population of women in the reproductive age group.
subject: PSM

question_text: To assess the effects of the national population policy, data is being collected at the PHC level. You have been asked to submit data regarding the approximate magnitude of completed family size in the population under your PHC. Which of the following indicators will you calculate?
explanation: The total fertility rate is an indicator of the approximate magnitude of completed family size.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the infant mortality rate in India as per the SRS Statistical Report (2020)?
explanation: The infant mortality rate (IMR) in India as per the SRS statistical report (2020) is 28 per 1000 live births. IMR is defined as the number of infant deaths for every 1000 live births. As per the National Family Health Survey - 5 (2019-2021), the IMR is 35.2 per 1000 live births. IMR is considered the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care.
subject: PSM

question_text: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a country is best given as
explanation: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the maternal mortality ratio in India according to the Special Bulletin on Maternal Mortality (2018-2020) based on SRS data?
explanation: The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) in India according to the Special Bulletin (2018-2020) based on SRS data is 97. MMR is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. The most common causes of maternal mortality in India are postpartum hemorrhage and infections.
subject: PSM

question_text: While collecting data for the census, which of the following people would you consider to be literate?
options: A person who is able to read, write and understand in any language
A person who is not able to read or write but can sign legal documents
A person who is able to speak fluently in his native language but is not able to read or write
A person who is able to read, but may not be able to write
explanation: A person is considered literate if he or she can read, write and understand in any language.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the denominator of the formula used to calculate effective literacy rate?
options: Population less than 15 years of age
explanation: The denominator used to calculate the effective literacy rate is the population aged 7 years or more. It is calculated as follows. Effective literacy rate = Number of literate persons aged 7 and above x 100/ Population aged 7 and above in a given year. This rate is generally used in Indian censuses including those in 1991, 2001, and 2011 for estimating literacy.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are studying the literacy rate of a community with a total population of 10000. Out of these, there are 2000 children from 0-6 years of age, and 4000 literate individuals above 7 years of age. What is the effective literacy rate of this population?
explanation: The effective literacy rate of this population is 50%. It is calculated as follows, Effective literacy rate = (Number of literate persons aged 7 and above x 100) / population aged 7 and above in a given year. In the given scenario, people aged 7 years and above = 10000 - 2000 = 8000. Out of these 8000 people, 4000 are literate. Thus, effective literacy rate = 4000 x 100/8000 = 50%.
subject: PSM

question_text:
Which of the following is false regarding the criteria for an urban Indian city?
Having 5000 or more inhabitants
options: Having a density of 390 persons per square km
At least half of the adult male population employed in occupations other than agriculture
explanation: In an urban area, at least three-fourths of the adult male population are employed in occupations other than agriculture. In the Indian context, the urban areas are places: having 5,000 or more inhabitants having a density of not less than 1,000 persons per square mile or 390 per square kilometer having pronounced urban characteristics having at least three-fourths of the adult male population employed in pursuits other than agriculture Family Planning
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the number of eligible couples per 1000 population in India?
explanation: There are approximately 150 – 180 eligible couples per 1000 population in India. An eligible couple refers to a currently married couple wherein the wife belongs to the reproductive age group (15-49 years of age).
subject: PSM

question_text: Scope of modern concept of family planning services include all of the following except:
explanation: Screening for HIV infection does not come under the purview of family planning. The modern concepts of family planning services include: Proper spacing and limitation of birth Advice on sterility Education for parenthood Sex education Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g. cervical cancer) Genetic counseling Premarital consultation and examination Pregnancy tests Marriage counseling Preparation of couples for the first child Providing services to unmarried mothers Teaching home economics and nutrition Providing adoption services
subject: PSM

question_text: A study was conducted in a village with 180 eligible couples, to gather data on the different contraceptive methods used. The data obtained are given below. What is the couple protection rate in the village?
explanation: Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning. In the given scenario, 60 out of 180 eligible couples are using different contraceptive methods. Therefore, CPR = (60/180) x 100 = 33%.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a barrier method of contraception?
explanation: Lippes loop is an intrauterine device and not a barrier method of contraception. Barrier methods of contraception include: Physical methods – male and female condoms, diaphragm, vaginal sponge (Today) Chemical methods – foam tablets, aerosols, creams, jellies, suppositories, and soluble films (C-films)
subject: PSM

question_text: A sexually active woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does this contain?
explanation: Today is a type of vaginal sponge that contains 9 – nonoxynol. Today is a barrier contraceptive inserted vaginally. It has to be left in place for 6 hours after coitus. It can lead to toxic shock syndrome if left in place for more than 24 hours (rarely).
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a second-generation intra-uterine device?
explanation: Nova T and Cu-T-380 Ag are second-generation intrauterine devices (IUD). IUD is a contraceptive method inserted into the uterine cavity. The different generations of IUDs include: First-generation IUDs – inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop Second-generation IUDs - medicated with metallic elements like copper eg: Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-375 Third-generation IUDs – hormone-containing IUDs like progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20)
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following women will not be considered ideal candidates for IUD insertion?
options: A woman in a monogamous relationship
A woman with no access to follow up
A woman who has at least one living child
explanation: A woman with no access to follow-up is not considered an ideal candidate for IUD insertion. An ideal candidate for an IUD must have the following attributes: Has at least one child No history of pelvic disease Normal menstrual periods Must be willing to check IUD tail Has access to follow up and for treatment of potential problems Is in a monogamous relationship
subject: PSM

question_text: A patient who underwent an IUD insertion is most likely to develop which of the following in the future?
explanation: Patients who underwent IUD insertion are most likely to develop vaginal bleeding in the future. Side effects and complications of IUDs include: Vaginal bleeding – most common Abdominal pain – second most common Pelvic infection Uterine perforation Pregnancy - due to failure of contraception Ectopic pregnancy Expulsion of the IUD Cancer and teratogenicity
subject: PSM

question_text: Insertion of an IUD is not contraindicated in patients with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Cardiac problems are not a contraindication for IUD usage. Contraindications for IUD usage include: Absolute contraindications Relativecontraindications Suspected pregnancyPIDVagi nal bleeding of unknown etio logyCarcinoma cervix/uterus/ adnexa /other pelvic tumors AnemiaMenorrhagiaHistory of PID since the last pregnan cyPurulent cervical discharge Distortions of the uterine cav ity due tofibroidsUterine mal formationsAn unmotivated p erson

question_text: Which of the following has the longest period of use?
explanation: Cu-T-380 A has the longest period of use (10 years). IUD Years of se Progestase rt 1 Cu-T-200 4 Nova T 5 LNG IUD 7-10 Cu-T-380 A 10

question_text: You have prescribed an IUCD to a multiparous woman. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action for this type of contraceptive?
explanation: Prevention of ovulation is not a mechanism of action of IUCDs. Mechanisms of action of IUCDs include: Causing cellular and biochemical changes in the uterus and endometrium. Prevention of sperm penetration due to changes in cervical mucus consistency. Prevention of implantation by making the uterus hostile to it.
subject: PSM

question_text: All of the following are non-contraceptive benefits of oral contraceptive pills except?
explanation: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) do not confer protection against thyroid dysfunction. OCP usage can confer protection against: Benign breast diseases like fibroadenoma and fibrocystic disease Ovarian cysts Iron-deficiency anemia Pelvic inflammatory disease Ectopic pregnancy Ovarian cancer
subject: PSM

question_text: In patients with which of the following conditions can OCPs be safely prescribed?
explanation: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is not a contraindication for prescribing OCPs. Absolute contraindications of OCPs: (CULT) Cancers - breast and genital Cardiac abnormalities Congenital hyperlipidemia Undiagnosed AUB Liver disease Thromboembolism - past or present history. Medical surveillance is required while prescribing OCPs if the patient is/or has: Age more than 40 years Chronic smoker and age over 35 years Amenorrhea Chronic renal disease Diabetes mellitus Epilepsy In the first 6 months of nursing Gall bladder disease History of infrequent bleeding Mild hypertension Migraine
subject: PSM

question_text: A sexually active woman who was using barrier contraceptives is planning on switching to DMPA injectables. Which of the following is the correct dosage of this contraceptive?
explanation: The dosage for injectable depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is 150 mg every 3 months. It acts by: Bringing changes in the cervical mucus Making the endometrium hostile Preventing ovulation Disadvantages include spotting and intermediate per vaginal bleeding.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is also known as the Billings method of contraception?
explanation: Billings method of contraception is also known as the cervical mucus method (or ovulation method). It is a natural method of contraception. It is based on the observation of changes in the cervical mucus. At ovulation, the mucus is watery clear, smooth, slippery and profuse. After ovulation, it becomes thicker and scarce. The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below:
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the most effective natural method of contraception?
explanation: The most effective natural method of contraception is the symptothermic method. It combines: Calendar method Cervical mucus method Basal body method. In this method, if a woman is not able to identify one sign, she can double-check with her interpretation of the other signs.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a condition to be fulfilled by a male patient undergoing sterilization?
options: Has at least one living child
Age should be more than 60 years
explanation: A man should be below 60 years of age to be eligible for sterilization. Eligibility for male sterilization: Clients should be at least 22 years old Clients should be below the age of 60 years Clients should be married The couple should have at least one child, whose age is above one year unless the sterilization is medically indicated Clients or their spouses must not have undergone sterilization in the past (not applicable in the cases of failure of previous sterilization) Clients must be in a sound state of mind, so as to understand the full implications of sterilization Mentally ill clients must be certified by a psychiatrist, and a statement should be given by the legal guardian/spouse regarding the soundness of the client's state of mind
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of failure of vasectomy?
explanation: The most common cause of failure of vasectomy is the mistaken identification of the vas. This can be avoided by examining a stained smear prepared by squeezing the vas on a glass slide. If facilities are available a histological examination is preferred. Causes of failure of vasectomy include: Mistaken identification of the vas - most common Spontaneous recanalization of the vas Presence of more than one vas on one side Sexual intercourse before the disappearance of sperms from the reproductive tracts
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is important in the calculation of the pearl index?
options: Total number of women in the population
explanation: The numerator used for calculation of the pearl index is total accidental pregnancies. Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure
subject: PSM

question_text:
As part of the National family planning program, you are conducting a study in a village to gather data on the efficacy of a new contraceptive. 20 out of 100 women became pregnant in the village despite using this contraceptive for a period of 2 years continuously. What is the
pearl index of this contraceptive?
explanation: In the given scenario, the pearl index is 10 per HWY. Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 20. The total months of exposure are 24 months for each woman. Hence, the total months of exposure for 100 women are 24 x 100 = 2400. Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/ Total months of exposure Hence, pearl index= 20 x 1200/2400 = 10 per HWY
subject: PSM

question_text:
Out of 100 women who took oral contraceptive pills for contraception, 10 women got pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl index?
10 per HWY
explanation: In the given scenario, the pearl index is 5 per HWY. Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10. There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method. So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400. Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure Hence, pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per HWY. Preventive Obstetrics, Pediatrics and Geriatrics
subject: PSM

question_text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
explanation: This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to the Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH). The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4. 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected. 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule: Once a month during the first 7 months Twice a month during the 8th month Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are a medical officer in a PHC. A pregnant woman comes to you for regular follow-up during her second trimester. Which of the following will you prescribe for her?
options: 100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid
100 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg folic acid
50 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg of folic acid
explanation: As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid in the II trimester. It should be started from the 4th month of pregnancy and continued for 180 days post-partum.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy?
explanation: Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it is a live vaccine. The live attenuated varicella virus vaccine is currently recommended for children between 12 to 18 months of age who have not had chickenpox.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the average weight gain during pregnancy in Indian women with inadequate calorie intake?
explanation: Weight gain during pregnancy in women with inadequate calorie intake is around 5 - 6 kgs. Normally, a woman is expected to gain around 9-11 kgs of weight during pregnancy. An inadequate dietary intake can be suspected if the woman gains < 2 kg/ month.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about congenital syphilis?
options: It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration
Infection of fetus most commonly occurs in the 1st trimester
Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication
Chances of transmission are lower if mother has late syphilis
explanation: The chances of transmission of syphilis during pregnancy is highest after 6th month of gestation. It does not occur before the 4th month. It is routine to test the mother for syphilis in antenatal clinics during her first visit. The chance of infection of the fetus is higher when the mother is suffering from early (primary or secondary) syphilis and are lower in case of late syphilis. Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication of congenital syphilis. It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration.
subject: PSM

question_text: The District Maternal Death Review Committee is reviewing the number of maternal deaths in the district during 2020. In order to calculate the maternal mortality ratio, what other parameter is required?
options: Total women in child bearing age
explanation: The maternal mortality ratio is calculated using the number of maternal deaths and total live births.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following maternal deaths is not included when calculating the maternal mortality ratio?
options: Death of a 30-year-old woman following spontaneous abortion at 11 weeks of gestation
Death of a 24-year-old woman due to ruptured ectopic pregnancy
Death of a 26-year-old woman following a road traffic accident at 36 weeks of gestation
Death of a 21-year-woman following secondary PPH on postpartum day 14
explanation: The death of a pregnant woman following a road traffic accident is not included when calculating the maternal mortality ratio. It includes all deaths anytime during pregnancy or within 42 days of termination from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the most common cause of maternal deaths in India?
explanation: The most common cause of maternal deaths in India is hemorrhage.
subject: PSM

question_text: In a town, there were 2500 live births in a period of 6 months. During the same period, 15 women died due to the following causes. What is the maternal mortality ratio?
explanation: The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) of this town is 400 per 100,000 live births. Maternal mortality refers to deaths during pregnancy or 42 days within termination, from causes related to pregnancy. Hence, in this town, there were 10 maternal deaths (peripartum infection, PPH, obstructed labor). MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 / Number of live births in the same period Hence, MMR = 10 x 100000/2500 = 400 per 100,000 live births
subject: PSM

explanation: Under the Home Based Newborn Care (HBNC) guidelines, ASHA workers should visit all newborns up to 42 days of life, according to the following schedule. question_text: What is the best indicator of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
explanation: The perinatal mortality rate is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth.

question_text: What is the 2030 target of the India Newborn Action Plan with regards to the stillbirth rate?
explanation: The India Newborn Action Plan targets to achieve a stillbirth rate of < 10/ 1000 live births and neonatal mortality rate of < 10/ 1000 live births (single-digit SBR and NMR) by 2030. This program was launched to reduce preventable newborn deaths and stillbirths. It provides the following: Pre-conception and antenatal care Care during labor and childbirth Immediate newborn care Care of healthy newborn Care of small and sick newborn Care beyond newborn survival
subject: PSM

question_text: A group of health workers are conducting a perinatal mortality audit in a hospital. Which of the following must they take into account to calculate the perinatal mortality rate?
explanation: The perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is calculated using the following parameters during a particular time period: Late fetal deaths or stillbirths > 1000 g - correlates to 28 weeks of gestation Early neonatal deaths - from birth to 7 days of life Live births > 1000 g The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) refers to the deaths within the first 28 days of life. It is calculated using the following parameters: Early neonatal deaths Late neonatal deaths - after 7th day but before 28th completed day of life
subject: PSM

question_text: In a given population, 4050 births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate of this population?
explanation: The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 50 per 1000 live births. Neonatal mortality rate = No. of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year In this population, there were 4000 live births (no. of total births - no. of stillbirths). NMR = (50+150) x 1000/4000 = 100/2 = 50

question_text: Which of the following is the leading cause of neonatal mortality?
explanation: Prematurity is the leading cause of neonatal mortality.

question_text: In children aged 1 month to 1 year, all of the following are common causes of mortality except:
explanation: Tetanus is not a common cause of mortality in children between the age of 1 month to 1 year (post-neonatal period). The main causes of post-neonatal deaths are diarrhea, respiratory infections, and malnutrition.
subject: PSM

question_text: In a given population, there were 5100 births during the year 2020. Of these, 100 babies were stillborn. Among the living children, the following deaths were recorded. Calculate the infant mortality rate for this population.
explanation: The infant mortality rate (IMR) for this population is 100 / 1000 live births. IMR = No. of deaths within 1st year of life over a period of time x 1000 / No. of live births in the same period In this population, there were 5000 live births (5100 – 100) and 500 deaths within the 1st year of life. Hence, IMR = 500 x 1000/5000 = 100 per 1000 live births

question_text: You are a doctor at a child health clinic. You will consider all of the following children as at-risk infants except:

explanation: The 2-month-old baby with 3 older siblings has a birth order of 4. Infants with birth order of 5 or more are considered at-risk infants. question_text: A researcher is calculating the child survival indices for different populations. Which of the following should he use for calculating the same?

question_text: A juvenile delinquent was sentenced by the court to be placed in a center under the care of a doctor and psychiatrist. Which of the following fulfills this requirement?
explanation: A remand home is an establishment where children are placed under the care of a doctor, psychiatrist and other trained personnel. An orphanage or shelter home is an institution where children who have no home or parents or for some reason can’t be cared for are placed. Foster homes are arrangements where a family or a couple takes care of a child on a temporary basis. Borstal is a place that falls between a certified institution and a prison. It is where boys > 16 years who have misbehaved or are too difficult to handle are sent.

question_text: The police authorities rescued a girl from being trafficked for sexual exploitation. She is identified to be a refugee. As a part of the Ujjawala scheme, which of the following benefits will she not receive?
explanation: The girl will not receive remuneration (monetary compensation) under the Ujjawala scheme. The Ujjawala scheme was launched to combat women and child trafficking in India. question_text: A 4-year-old girl was brought by her parents who tell you that she fell down while playing. On examination, bruises and ecchymoses of varying ages are noted all over the body. question_text: As a PHC medical officer, which of the following groups would you target as a part of Kishori Shakti Yojana?
explanation: The Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) program is aimed at adolescent girls (11-18 years). This program is a component of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme and is a redesign of the already existing Adolescent Girls (AG) scheme. The objectives of KSY are: To improve the nutrition, health, and development status To promote awareness on health, hygiene, nutrition, and family care To teach life skills and encourage school attendance To help understand their social environment Aspects aimed at empowerment and enhanced self-perception To help them take initiatives to become productive members of society It also fosters convergence with other sectoral programs, addressing the interrelated needs of adolescent girls and women.
subject: PSM

question_text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
explanation: The school health programs are managed by the primary health center (PHC). The School Health Committee (1961) in India recommended that the school health services should be a part of the general health services administered through PHCs. Formation of school health committees at the village, block, district, state, and national levels was recommended. The National School Health Council was created as an advisory and coordinating body. PHCs provide the following school health services: Screening and general assessments for - Anemia/nutritional status Visual acuity and hearing problems Dental check-up Physical disabilities Learning disorders and behavior problems Basic medicines for common ailments Immunization Micronutrient management (vitamin A, iron, and folic acid) Deworming Mid-day meal
