question_text: A 68-year-old man visits your outpatient clinic for a routine follow-up. Which of the following protocols would you use to assess his health literacy?
explanation: The SPEAK protocol is used to assess health literacy in the geriatric population in a clinical setting. Health literacy is defined as the degree to which individuals have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information needed to make appropriate health decisions. The SPEAK protocol provides a simple framework that healthcare providers can use to assess literacy. SPEAK stands for: S - Speech P - Perception E - Education A - Access K - Knowledge Option A: The GATHER approach is mainly used for counseling (usually, family planning and reproductive counseling) to help people make decisions about health. It stands for: G – Greet A – Ask T – Tell H – Help E – Explain R – Return Option C: The SPIKES protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organized manner to patients and families. It stands for: S - Setting P - Perception I - Invitation or information K - Knowledge E - Empathy S - Summarizing or strategizing. Option D: The S-BAR technique is used for prompt and appropriate communication among health care workers in hospital settings. It stands for: S - Situation B - Background A - Assessment R - Recommendation

question_text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the following would you advise him to eat?

The result lies on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score. The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute. In 2021, India's GHI was 27.5. It ranks 101 among 116 countries. In the 2022,India's GHI stands at 29.1, and India ranks 107th out of the 121 countries. Safe and wholesome water is defined as: Free from pathogenic agents Free from harmful chemicals Pleasant to taste, free from colour and odour Usable for domestic purposes Water is said to be polluted when it does not fulfill the above criteria.
subject: PSM

question_text: In an urban PHC, an increasing number of skin diseases are being reported due to inadequate water supply in the region. What would be the adequate supply of water for them to meet their needs for all domestic purposes?
explanation: The given scenario of skin diseases is suggestive of water-washed diseases caused by improper hygiene related to an inadequate water supply. In urban areas, 150–200 litres per capita per day is the recommended allowance to meet the needs for all kinds of domestic purposes. In rural areas, the set target of water supply to be achieved in India is around 50-55 litres per capita per day.
subject: PSM

question_text: What are the norms for the required litres of water per capita per day in rural areas?
explanation: According to the National Rural Drinking Water Programme, the requirement of water in rural areas (areas with public water posts) is 55 litres per capita per day. This is in accordance with the 12th Five Year Plan. For reasons of comparability, the source of water provision in rural areas should be within a distance of 100 metres from the household or the time taken to fetch water should not be > 30 minutes. Note: Park textbook mentions 40-50 litres per capita per day as the norm. However, in the 12th five year plan period, the Government of India enhanced the rural drinking water supply norms from 40 litres to 55 litres per capita per day.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the purest form of water in nature?
explanation: Rain water is the purest form of water in nature. It contains a very low amount of total dissolved solids (TDS). Rain water is the origin of both surface and ground water. Sources of water: Rain Surface water: Impounding reservoirs Rivers and streams Tanks, ponds and lakes Ground water: Shallow wells Deep wells Springs
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a source of surface water?
explanation: Shallow wells are sources of ground water. Sources of water: Rain Surface water: Impounding reservoirs Rivers and streams Tanks, ponds and lakes Ground water: Shallow wells Deep wells Springs
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the area from which water drains into impounding reservoirs known as?
explanation: The area draining into the impounding reservoirs are known as catchment areas. Impounding reservoirs are also called embankment ponds. These reservoirs are artificial lake-like water bodies. They are made by building an embankment or earth fill in an area into which natural water flows and can be stored for usage. Dams are also built to create these reservoirs. Water from these reservoirs is second in purity to rainwater but is not completely free from impurities. Catchment areas are the main sources of impurities in the water in impounding reservoirs. The image given below shows catchment area:
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the most common type of well in India?
explanation: Dug wells are the most common type of wells in India.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about artesian wells?
options: It is not common in India
Water is put under pressure between two impervious layers
No pump is required to bring water to surface
It is a type of shallow we
explanation: Artesian wells are types of deep wells.
subject: PSM

question_text: Step wells belong to which of the following types of wells?
explanation: Step wells belong to the type of pucca dug wells.
subject: PSM

question_text: An outbreak of guinea worm disease was reported among villagers who used step wells for drinking water. In order to arrest the spread of disease, a decision was made to replace step wells with sanitary and safe wells. All of the following measures would be considered during its construction except:
options: Must be located at least 15 metres away from sources of contamination
A partition space for washing clothes and vessels
Lining must be made to a depth of 6 metres or more
Hand-pump must be made to handle rough use
explanation: Washing clothes, vessels, and bathing must be prohibited around wells to avoid contamination of the water. Step wells are a type of pucca wells which enable people to descend into the well to fetch water. It is obsolete now, as there is considerable personal contact between the user and the water which can pose a health hazard to the community.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the minimum length that the platform of a well should extend around it in all directions?
explanation: The platform of a sanitary well should stretch for at least 1 metre around the well in all directions.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a water-washed disease?
explanation: Cholera is a water-borne disease and not a water-washed disease. The diseases which are transmitted by improper hygiene and are widely related to circumstances where there is inadequate water supply are called water-washed diseases. Some examples of water-washed diseases are: Conjunctivitis Trachoma Scabies Typhus
subject: PSM

question_text: A multipurpose worker is spraying herbicides on aquatic plants as part of vector control measures in your area. Which of the following water-related diseases can be controlled by this approach?
explanation: Filariasis (caused by B.malayi) is transmitted by Mansonia species of mosquito that breeds in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation. It can be controlled by the use of herbicides to destroy aquatic vegetation. Water-related diseases are classified as: Category Examples Water-borne diseases Caused by ingestion of water contaminated by human or a nimal faeces, or urine contai ning pathogenic bacteria or v iruses.ex: Cholera, typhoid, a moebic and bacillary dysente ry, and other diarrhoeal disea ses. Water-washed diseases Caused by poor personal hygi ene.ex: Scabies, trachoma, fle a-, lice- and tick-borne diseas es, in addition to the majorit y of waterborne diseases (whi ch are also water-washed). Water-based diseases Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms livin g in water.ex: Dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis and some ot her helminths. Category Examples Category Examples Water-related diseases trans mitted by insect vectors Caused by vectors that breed in waterex: Dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, tryp anosomiasis and yellow fever.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following methods of purification of water cannot be used on a large scale?
explanation: Berkefeld filter is used for the purification of water on a small scale (ex: in households).
subject: PSM

question_text: During your posting as a rural medical officer, you conduct an awareness drive prior to the monsoon season in order to highlight the necessity of water purification. Which of the following methods would you not recommend for a household setup?
explanation: Slow sand filter is a method of filtration used for the purification of water on a large scale.
subject: PSM

question_text: When river water is stored properly, by how much percent does the bacterial count drop in the first 5-7 days?
explanation: When river water is stored properly, the bacterial count drops by as much as 90% in the first 5 – 7 days. Purification during the storage of water is a natural process that takes place by physical, chemical and biological phenomena. Components of water purification include storage, filtration and disinfection.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the other name for slow sand filters?
explanation: Slow sand filters are also called biological filters.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a part of a slow sand filter?
explanation: Components of a slow sand filter include: Under-drainage system Sand bed and a layer of organic matter Filter control system Supernatant water Filter box
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about slow sand filters?
options: The thickness of sand bed is 2 metres
It takes a longer duration for water purification
The sand grain size is 0.4 to 0.7 mm
explanation: Slow sand filters take a longer duration than most other methods for purification of water.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following best describes Schmutzdecke?
options: Layer of alum flocculate on supernatant water
Layer of algae and diatoms on supernatant water
Layer of alum flocculate on surface of sand bed filter
Layer of algae and diatoms on surface of sand bed filter
explanation: Schmutzdecke refers to the vital layer which is formed by algae, plankton, diatoms and bacteria on the surface of the sand bed filter.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not the vital layer of a slow sand filter?
explanation: The vital layer of a slow sand filter is also called the zoogleal layer, Schmutzdecke, or the biological layer.
subject: PSM

question_text: Where is the vital layer of the slow sand filter seen?
options: On top of the raw water
explanation: The vital layer of the slow sand filter is seen on the sand bed.
subject: PSM

question_text: What does the venturi meter measure in a slow sand filter?
explanation: Venturi meters measure the bed resistance or loss of head in a slow sand filter. The following image shows a venturi meter:
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about rapid sand filters?
options: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity or pressure type
explanation: Frequent washing of the filter bed is required in rapid sand filters. This is done by backwashing.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the effective size of sand grains in a rapid sand filter?
explanation: Effective size of sand grains in a rapid sand filter is 0.4 – 0.7 mm. Effective size of sand grains in a slow sand filter is 0.2 – 0.3 mm.
subject: PSM

question_text: Rapid sand filter is different from the slow sand filter by which of the following features?
options: Sand particles are of smaller size
explanation: Skilled labor is required for rapid sand filters. Unskilled labor is enough for slow sand filters. Comparison of rapid and slow sand filters: Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter Space Occupies very little space Occupies large area Rate of filtration (million gall ons per acre per day) 200 m.g.a.d 2-3 m.g.a.d. Effective size of sand 0.4-0.7 mm 0.2-0.3 mm Preliminary treatment Chemical coagulation and se dimentation Plain sedimentation Washing By back-washing By scraping the sand be d Operation Highly skilled Less skilled Loss of head allowed 6-8 feet (2- 2.5 m) 4 feet (1.5 m) Removal of bacteria 98-99% 99.9- 99.99%
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a ceramic filter that can be used for small scale purification of water?
explanation: Filtration of water on a small scale is done by ceramic filters like Pasteur Chamberland, Berkefeld, and Katadyn filters. Ceramic filters are not widely used in India. The most important parts of these filters are the filter candles. Filter candles of the fine type help in removing bacteria but not viruses. These filter candles need to be cleaned periodically as they get clogged with impurities and bacteria. Types of ceramic filters include: Pasteur Chamberland filter – It has a candle made of porcelain. Image of a Pasteur Chamberland filter is shown below: Berkefeld filter - it has a candle made of infusorial earth or kieselguhr. Image of a Berkefeld filter is shown below: Katadyn filter - the surface of this filter is coated with a silver catalyst. The incoming bacteria are killed on contact with the surface by the oligodynamic action of silver ions which are liberated into the water. Image of a Katadyn filter is shown below:
subject: PSM

question_text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect about ceramic filters?
Surface of Berkefeld filter is lined with a silver catalyst
options: Chamberland filter has a porcelain filter candle
Oligodynamic action is seen with Katadyn filter
They are not widely used in India
explanation: Berkefeld filter has a candle made of infusorial earth or kieselguhr. Ceramic filters are used for small scale purification of water. They are not widely used in India. The most important parts of these filters are the filter candles. Types of ceramic filters include: Pasteur Chamberland filter – It has a candle made of porcelain. Berkefeld filter - it has a candle made of infusorial earth or kieselguhr. Katadyn filter - the surface of this filter is coated with a silver catalyst. The incoming bacteria are killed on contact with the surface by the oligodynamic action of silver ions which are liberated into the water. Water- II: Disinfection of water
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the method of choice for the purification of highly polluted water on a large scale?
explanation: Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is done for purification of highly polluted water on a large scale.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding chlorination of water?
options: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven
It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for its disinfectant activity
explanation: Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven because of the predominance of the hypochlorous acid. Most water sources have a pH around 6.5–7, making chlorination an effective form of disinfection. Option A: Orthotolidine test measures both free and combined chlorine in water. Option C: Chlorination kills pathogenic bacteria, but has no effect on spores and certain viruses. Option D: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid.
subject: PSM

question_text: You assign a male health worker at a sub-centre with the task of chlorinating public water resources. What is the minimum concentration of free residual chlorine that should be maintained for effective chlorination?
options: 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour
0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour
explanation: The minimum recommended concentration of free residual chlorine for routine chlorination is 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour.
subject: PSM

question_text:
As an epidemiologist, you are investigating an outbreak of cholera. What is the minimum free residual chlorine level that should be maintained in pipelines to prevent further spread of the
outbreak?
explanation: The minimum level of free residual chlorine to be maintained in pipelines following an outbreak of cholera is 0.5 mg/litre. After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of faeces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of free residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higher i.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/litre.
subject: PSM

question_text: The municipal corporation in your area is performing routine chlorination of drinking water supplies. Which of the following statements about chlorination is incorrect?
options: Free chlorine is released in water after breakpoint chlorination
Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill spores, protozoal cysts and helminthic ova
0.5 ppm of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached
Contact period of 1 hour is necessary
explanation: Chlorine demand is the amount of chlorine that is needed to kill bacteria, and to oxidize all the organic matter and ammoniacal substances in the water. It is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 1 hour) at a given temperature and pH of the water. 0.5 ppm (0.5 mg) of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following tests identifies free and combined chlorine in water separately?
explanation: Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both free and combined chlorine in water separately. Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorine together. Chick Martin test and Garrod's test are used to test the efficacy of disinfectants.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property of bleaching powder?
explanation: The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions. Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows: H2O + Cl2  HCl + HOCl HOCl  H + OCl
subject: PSM

question_text: A village health and sanitation team is planning to disinfect 100 wells. Which of the following is the most cost-effective method in this scenario?
explanation: Disinfection of wells using bleaching powder is the most widely used and cheapest method.
subject: PSM

question_text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A has been reported in a village. On investigating, you find a contaminated well in the locality to be the source of the outbreak. Which of the following methods would you advise for chlorinating the well in this scenario?
explanation: The double pot method is used for disinfecting wells by chlorination in emergencies like hepatitis A outbreak in a village. Double pot method has an inner and outer pot, each with a hole in it and covered with a polyethylene foil. The inner pot is filled with bleaching powder and coarse sand. The double pot system is then lowered into a well. This device can work satisfactorily for 2 – 3 weeks in small wells containing about 4500 litres of water.
subject: PSM

question_text: In your community medicine practicals, you are given an apparatus as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements regarding the apparatus is true?
options: The indicator used is bromocresol purple
It is used to estimate free chlorine levels
It is used to estimate combined chlorine levels
explanation: The image given is that of a Horrock's apparatus. The indicator used in Horrock's apparatus is starch iodide. Horrock's apparatus contains 6 white cups (200 ml each), 1 black cup with a circular mark, 2 metal spoons with 2 grams of bleaching powder in each, 7 glass stirring rods, 1 special pipette and 2 droppers. It is not usful in measuring free and combined chlorine. It estimates the chlorine demand of water and is used to calculate the amount of bleaching powder used to disinfect the well.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water if the 4th, 5th, and 6th cups of a Horrock’s apparatus show distinct blue color?
explanation: The dose of bleaching powder required is 8 grams. It is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 litres of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows distinct blue color. In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water is (4 x 2) = 8grams.
subject: PSM

question_text: The water sample from a well is tested using Horrock’s apparatus. It is observed that the 3rd cup shows a blue color after the addition of the starch-iodine indicator. How much bleaching powder will be required to disinfect 2275 litres of the well water?
explanation: The dose of bleaching powder required is 30 grams. It is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 liters of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows a distinct blue color. In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is (3 x 2) = 6 grams. Since 2275/455 = 5. The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 2275 litres of water = 6 x 5 = 30 grams.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following agents have residual germicidal effect when used for treatment of water?
explanation: Chlorine has residual germicidal effect when used for treatment of water. UV radiation, ozone gas, iodine and potassium permanganate have good germicidal action but do not have residual germicidal effect.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following properties of ozone makes it less suitable for the disinfection of water on a large scale?
options: Ozone requires a long time period for action
It has no residual disinfectant action
explanation: Ozone has no residual disinfectant action. Ozone gas can be used as a primary disinfectant of water in a large scale. Ozone disinfection is usually followed by biological filtration or granular activated carbon to prevent further contamination during distribution. Chlorine residual treatment is also done as ozone does not provide for a residual disinfectant action.
subject: PSM

question_text:
Which of the following is a lower-pressure membrane process for treatment of water?
Reverse osmosis
explanation: Microfiltration is a lower-pressure membrane process used for the treatment of water. Membrane processes are employed in the large scale treatment of water. They are classified as high-pressure processes and lower-pressure processes. High-pressure processes: Reverse osmosis - Rejects monovalent ions and organic molecules of molecular weight > 50 daltons. It is most commonly used for desalination of brackish water and sea water. The membrane pore size is < 0.002 µm. Nanofiltration - Allows monovalent ions such as sodium or potassium to pass but rejects a high proportion of divalent ions like calcium and magnesium and some higher molecular weight organics. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.001 – 0.01 µm. Lower-pressure processes: Ultrafiltration - Rejects organic molecules of molecular weight > 800 daltons. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.002 - 0.003 µm. Microfiltration - Rejects colloidal and suspended material. It does not separate molecules and is usually used before reverse osmosis. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.01 – 12 µm. Water - III: Water Quality and Standards
subject: PSM

question_text: Above what level does the turbidity of water become visible to the naked eye?
explanation: Turbidity of water becomes visible to the naked eye above 4 nephelometric turbidity units (NTU). The ideal level of turbidity is <1.0 NTU for household drinking purposes. However, in situations where this is not achievable, the maximum permissible limit is <5 NTU.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the maximum permissible level of chloride in drinking water?
explanation: The maximum permissible level of chloride in drinking water is 600 mg/litre.
subject: PSM

question_text: A detectable taste begins to appear in drinking water if chloride levels in it exceed:
explanation: A detectable taste begins to appear in drinking water if chloride levels in it exceed 250 mg/litre.
subject: PSM

question_text: A large number of cases of methemoglobinemia were reported among infants from a municipal area. On detailed investigation, the nitrate levels in drinking water were found to be elevated in that area. This complication can occur when nitrate level in drinking water exceeds:
explanation: Nitrates in the excess of 45 mg/L may cause methaemoglobinemia in infants.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which is the most undesirable metal in drinking water?
explanation: The most undesirable metal in drinking water is lead.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the acceptable level of total dissolved solids in drinking water in India?
explanation: According to the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS), the acceptable level of total dissolved solids (TDS) in drinking water in India is 500 mg/L. Note: There is a variation in the value of the acceptable level of total dissolved solids in drinking water provided by WHO and the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS). While the WHO sets the value at 600 mg/L, the BIS has set it at 500 mg/L for India.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the proposed guideline for the permissible radioactivity values for drinking water?
options: Gross alpha activity up to 0.1 Bq/L and gross beta activity up to 1 Bq/L
Gross alpha activity up to 1 Bq/L and gross beta activity up to 0.5 Bq/L
Gross alpha activity up to 0.5 Bq/L and gross beta activity up to 1 Bq/L
Gross alpha activity up to 0.1 Bq/L and gross beta activity up to 0.5 Bq/L
explanation: The proposed guideline for the permissible radioactivity values for drinking water is: Gross alpha activity up to 0.5 Bq/litre. Gross beta activity up to 1.0 Bq/litre.
subject: PSM

question_text: In view of a hepatitis A outbreak in a hostel, samples of drinking water are collected to detect fecal contamination. Presence of which of the following organisms serves as the most reliable evidence of fecal contamination?
explanation: The presence of Escherichia coli is the most suitable and reliable evidence of fecal contamination of water. Klebsiella aerogens is a typical example of the non-fecal group of coliform organisms.
subject: PSM

question_text: A microbiologist is testing a sample of drinking water to detect fecal contamination. The presence of all of the following organisms indicates a positive test result except:
explanation: Presence of Staphylococcus and Klebsiella aerogens does not indicate fecal contamination of water. Biological indicators of fecal pollution of water are: Streptococcus faecalis Escherichia coli Clostridium perfringens
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about water purification and pollution?
options: Presence of clostridial spores indicates recent contamination
Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate water
Coliforms must not be detectable in any 100 ml sample of drinking water
Coliforms can be detected by the multiple tube method
explanation: The presence of clostridial spores indicates remote or intermittent contamination of water.
subject: PSM

question_text: Multiple tube method is done for which of the following?
options: Detecting the presence of coliform organisms in a sample of water
Detecting the presence of enteric viruses in a sample of water
Estimating the levels of mercury in a sample of water
Estimating turbidity of a sample of water
explanation: The multiple tube method is done to detect the presence of coliform organisms in a sample of water. In order to estimate the presumptive coliform count, water to be tested is inoculated into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These tubes are then incubated and examined after an appropriate period of time. The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to other organisms. The proportion of false-positive reactions obtained depends both on the bacterial flora of the water under examination and the medium used. Lactose broth, or MacConkey's broth, with bromocresol purple as an indicator and a standardized concentration of bile salts incubated between 35°C–37°C for 48 hours, seems to be the most suitable media for presumptive tests.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the acceptable bacteriological quality of drinking water in small communities?
options: No coliform bacteria in 100 ml of water
Upto 10 coliform bacteria in 100 ml of water
Upto 10 coliform bacteria in 1000 ml of water
Upto 100 coliform bacteria in 1000 ml of water
explanation: There must be no coliform bacteria in any 100 ml sample of drinking water as its presence indicates fecal contamination.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following criteria is true for safe drinking water according to the WHO guidelines?
explanation: The desirable pH of safe drinking water ranges from 6.5 to 8.5. The maximum permissible level of chloride in drinking water is 0.6 g/L (600 mg/L), and that of nitrates is 0.05 g/L (50mg/l). The concentration of lead must be kept at <0.01 mg/L. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a criterion included in the guidelines for drinking water quality recommended by WHO?
explanation: According to WHO, the permissible level of color in drinking water is <15 true color units (TCU). The permissible level of turbidity in drinking water is <1 NTU. The permissible level of arsenic is up to 0.01 mg/l and nitrites is up to 3 mg/l.
subject: PSM

question_text: Temporary hardness of water is primarily due to the presence of which of the following?
explanation: The temporary hardness of water is primarily due to the presence of calcium and magnesium bicarbonates.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following does not cause hardness of water?
explanation: Calcium carbonate does not cause hardness of water. Hardness of water is caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium. There are two types of hardness of water: Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the level of hardness in soft water?
explanation: The level of hardness in soft water is <1 mEq/litre.
subject: PSM

question_text: How would you classify a water sample that has a level of hardness of 200 mg/litre?
explanation: When the level of hardness of water is in the range of 150 – 300 mg/litre, it is classified as hard water.
subject: PSM

question_text: A health worker is conducting periodic quality test for water sources in your area. What should be the hardness level of water used for drinking purposes?
explanation: Water used for drinking purposes must have a hardness level of 1 – 3 mEq/L (moderately hard).
subject: PSM

question_text: Above what level of hardness is softening of water recommended?
explanation: Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/l (150 mg/litre).
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a method of removal of hardness of water?
explanation: Filtration is not a method of removal of hardness of water. Methods for removal of hardness of water are: Boiling Addition of lime Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash) Base exchange process
subject: PSM

question_text:
What is the composition of permutit which is used for the base exchange process to remove hardness of water?
Sodium aluminium silicate
explanation: Permutit is a complex chemical compound made of sodium, aluminium and silica. It is used to remove hardness of water by base exchange process. Permutit has the property of ion exchange and removes calcium and magnesium from water. It removes both permanent and temporary hardness. Environmental Meteorology
subject: PSM

question_text: The water vapor and pollutants tend to get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere in winters. What is the reason behind this occurrence?
explanation: In winters, water vapor and pollutants get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere due to temperature inversion. This results in the formation of smog, especially in the winter months, and this is a possible threat to human health.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not an indicator of air pollution?
explanation: The heavy metal pollution index (HPI) is not an indicator of air pollution. It is a rating method and an effective tool to assess the water quality with respect to heavy metals. Indicators of air pollution: Sulfur dioxide - best indicator Smoke or soiling index Grit and dust measurement The co-efficient of haze Air pollution index Suspended particle matter (SPM)
subject: PSM

question_text: Which agency monitors air quality in India?
explanation: Central Pollution Control Board is the main body that monitors air quality in India and sets standards.
subject: PSM

question_text: Greenhouse gases include all of the following except:
explanation: Carbon monoxide is not a greenhouse gas. Greenhouse gases include: Water vapor Carbon dioxide Methane Tropospheric ozone Nitrous oxide Chlorofluorocarbons (non-natural)
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following protocols set the standard to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases internationally?
explanation: The Kyoto Protocol was an internal agreement to set internationally binding emission reduction targets. It is linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18% in the period between 2013-2020.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is true about global warming?
options: Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas
CFC increases ozone levels in the stratosphere
Kyoto Protocol called for 10% reduction in greenhouse emissions
explanation: Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas. Tropospheric ozone and chlorofluorocarbons are also important greenhouse gases. Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas, but the water vapor produced directly by human activity contributes very little to the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. Hence, its emissions have not been estimated. Greenhouse gases lead to global warming, which is the major cause of climate change. Climate change accelerates species extinction on earth.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding indoor air pollutants?
options: Carbon monoxide is produced by fuel combustion
Radon is an indoor air pollutant
Mercury vapor is a source of indoor air pollution
explanation: Mercury is not a source of indoor air pollution. Indoor air pollutants commonly arise from coal or fuel combustion. They include: Carbon monoxide Polyaromatic hydrocarbons Nitrogen Sulfur oxides Pesticides Asbestos Lead Radon
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in individuals affected by indoor air pollution?
explanation: Indoor air pollution has not been linked with neurodevelopmental disorders. It can result in a higher incidence of the following: Pregnancy complications Chronic lung disease Childhood pneumonia

question_text: What is ventilation provided by wind blowing through a space called?
explanation: Ventilation provided by wind blowing through a space is called perflation. Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical: Natural ventilation includes: Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors). Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other. The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible. Mechanical ventilation includes: Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space. Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out. Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation. Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.
subject: PSM

question_text:
What was the 10 days rule in radiation related to?
Occupational health
explanation: The 10 days rule in radiation was related to pregnancy. It is aimed at preventing unintentional exposure of the embryo or fetus to radiation. This rule states that if a radiograph is being done on the abdomen or pelvis of a woman in her childbearing age, then it should be done during the 10 days following the onset of menstruation. In most situations, there is growing evidence that strict adherence to the "ten-day rule" may be unnecessarily restrictive. Since organogenesis starts 3 to 5 weeks post-conception, it was felt that radiation exposure in early pregnancy couldn't result in malformation. Based on this, it was suggested to do away with the 10-day rule and replace it with a 28-day rule. This means that radiological examination if justified, can be carried throughout the cycle until a period is missed. Waste and Sewage Disposal

question_text: Which method is most appropriate when suitable land for waste disposal is available?

In this method, waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the day. This method is also called a sanitary landfill. Chemical, bacteriological and physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60° Celsius within 7 days. Methods used for controlled tipping are: Trench method Ramp method Area method Sewage farming is also a method of sewage disposal in places where sufficient and suitable land is available. It is also called land treatment or broad irrigation.
subject: PSM

question_text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
explanation: In controlled tipping, one acre of land is required by the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000. It is also known as a sanitary landfill. It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. In this method, waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared area. Then, it is adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day. Methods used in controlled tipping are: Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false about composting?
options: Bangalore method is an aerobic process
Mechanical composting uses a controlled environmen
Nightsoil can also be disposed with composting
Compost has few or no disease-causing pathogens
explanation: The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process. Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing pathogens. Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition will be completed. Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated.
subject: PSM

question_text: All of the following are methods of disposing only excreta except:
explanation: Bangalore method, also known as the hot fermentation process, is a form of composting that is used for disposing of both solid waste and nightsoil (excreta). Methods of excreta disposal: Unsewered areas: Service type latrines (conservancy system) - In this, nightsoil is collected manually from pail or bucket type latrines and then disposed of by burying or composting Non-service type latrines (sanitary latrines) Borehole latrine Dug well or pit latrine Water-seal latrines – Examples are P.R.A.I. type, R.C.A. type, and Sulabh shauchalaya Septic tanks Aqua privy Latrines for camps and temporary use Shallow and deep trench latrine Pit latrine Borehole latrine Sewered areas: Water carriage system and sewage treatmen Primary treatment – Screening, removal of grit and plain sedimentation Secondary treatment – Trickling filters, activated sludge process Other methods – sea and river outfalls, sewage farming, oxidation ponds
subject: PSM

question_text: A military camp is being set up in an area for one month. Which of the following latrines will not be suitable here?
explanation: Septic tanks cannot be used for camps and temporary purposes. Methods of excreta disposal: Unsewered areas: Service type latrines (conservancy system) - In this, nightsoil is collected manually from pail or bucket type latrines and then disposed of by burying or composting Non-service type latrines (sanitary latrines) Borehole latrine Dug well or pit latrine Water-seal latrines – Examples are P.R.A.I. type, R.C.A. type, and Sulabh shauchalaya Septic tanks Aqua privy Latrines for camps and temporary use Shallow and deep trench latrine Pit latrine Borehole latrine Sewered areas: Water carriage system and sewage treatmen Primary treatment – Screening, removal of grit and plain sedimentation Secondary treatment – Trickling filters, activated sludge process Other methods – sea and river outfalls, sewage farming, oxidation ponds
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the oldest non-service type of latrines in India?
explanation: The oldest non-service type of latrines in India is the borehole latrine. It was introduced in the 1930s to combat hookworm infections. Special equipment called auger is used to dig a borehole latrine. Advantages: No special staff is needed for upkeep as after using the latrine is closed and another hole is dug elsewhere Breeding of flies is less No water pollution if located far from a water source Demerits: Fills up rapidly Augers are not readily available Water pollution is still a risk
subject: PSM

question_text: There is an outbreak of hookworm infection in your locality. On investigation, it is found that the outbreak is a result of open-air defecation. The district council decides to construct an RCA type of latrine in every household. What is the optimum water seal required?
explanation: The optimum water seal required for an RCA type of latrine is 2 – 2.5 cm. It was designed by the Research-cum-Action Projects (RCA) in Environmental Sanitation of the Ministry of Health. Water seals aids in preventing flies and other organisms from reaching the waste. It also prevents the escape of odors and foul gases, eliminating the nuisance from the smell. Features of RCA type of latri ne Location More than 15m away from th e water source Squatting plate Should be impervious and sh ould allow for drainage of wa ter Pan Receives the nightsoil, urine, and washes water. Trap Holds the water and provides hewater seal.A good trap ha s an effective seal of around 2 – 2.5 cms. Connecting pipe Present in indirect type and a bsent in direct type Dug well Has to be changed after it is f illed Superstructure Built for privacy and shelter
subject: PSM

question_text: A health committee formed under Swachh Bharat Mission is involved in constructing septic tanks in every household. Which of the following is true about a septic tank?
explanation: The recommended retention period for a septic tank is 24 hours. If the retention period is too short, there is insufficient treatment of sewage and if it is too long, then undue septicity results. There are single and double-chambered septic tanks. The minimum capacity recommended for a septic tank is 500 gallons. The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false about the sewage treatment shown in the image below?
options: Desludging must be done at least once a year
Anaerobic digestion occurs inside the tank
Soap and disinfectants like phenol should not be used inside the tank
explanation: The given image is of a septic tank. It is not useful for very large communities and is used for household sewage treatment.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is wastewater without human excreta called?
explanation: Wastewater that doesn’t contain human excreta is called sullage. It is also called greywater. E.g., waste water from the kitchen. Sewage is wastewater from a community that contains solid and liquid excreta along with street and yard washings. It is also called blackwater.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the average amount of sewage which flows though the sewerage system in 24 hours known as?
explanation: The average amount of sewage which flows though the sewerage system in 24 hours is known as dry weather flow.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not used to express the strength of sewage?
explanation: E. coli count is not used to express the strength of sewage. The strength of sewage is expressed only in terms of: Biochemical oxygen demand Chemical oxygen demand Suspended solids
subject: PSM

question_text: What does the biochemical oxygen demand of sewage indicate?
explanation: Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) indicates the organic content of sewage. It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage for aerobic destruction by living microorganisms. If wastewater contains toxic substances, the organic load is measured by the chemical oxygen demand.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following values of biochemical oxygen demand would indicate that the sewage is weak?
explanation: Sewage with biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) of 100mg/L would indicate that it is weak. If the BOD is  300 mg/L, sewage is said to be strong.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary treatment of sewage?
explanation: Aeration tank is not a part of primary treatment of sewage. It is a part of secondary treatment of sewage.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the function of the grit chamber in modern sewage treatment plants?
options: Allow anaerobic auto-digestion of organic matter
explanation: The function of the grit chamber in modern sewage treatment plants is to allow heavier particles in the sewage to settle.
subject: PSM

question_text: Trickling filter method is used in which of the following?
explanation: The trickling filter method is used in secondary sewage treatment.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the heart of the activated sludge process?
explanation: The heart of the activated sludge process is the aeration tanks.
subject: PSM

question_text:
Which of the following is not a requirement for an oxidation pond?
Sunligh
explanation: Aeration is not a requirement for an oxidation pond. Oxidation ponds are also called waste stabilization ponds or redox ponds or sewage lagoons. They have become a popular method of purifying sewage for small communities. It is usually an open, shallow pool of around 1 – 1.5m depth with an inlet and outlet. Requisites for an oxidation pond include: Algae Saprophytic bacteria Sunligh All of the above factors help in the treatment of sewage waste through aerobic and anaerobic processes. The effluent formed can be used for land irrigation or can be forwarded for further treatment. Medical Entomology - Mosquitoes and Flies
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding mosquitoes?
options: It is the definitive host in malaria
Mansonia is a vector for Malayan filariasis
Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
All mosquitoes can travel only for 100 metres
explanation: Most mosquitoes can travel or fly for distances up to 11 kms.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following species of mosquitoes breed in dirty water and water bodies containing aquatic vegetation respectively?
explanation: Culex species of mosquitoes breed mostly in dirty and polluted water. Mansonia species of mosquitoes breed in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about larva of mosquitoes?
options: Culex larva lies in water with head faced downwards
Anopheles larva lies parallel to the undersurface of water
explanation: Anopheles larva has no siphon tube as shown in the image below. The image given below shows Culex larva having a siphon tube.
subject: PSM

question_text: Identify the species of mosquito shown in the image below.
explanation: The given image is of an Aedes mosquito. They can be identified with the stripes on the legs and body. They are also called tiger mosquitoes because of their stripes.
subject: PSM

question_text: A 25-year-old lady from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 4 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is given below. Which of the following is true about the mosquito which transmits this disease?
options: Keeps its body horizontal while feeding
explanation: The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing ring form/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. It is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. They have spotted wings. They breed in clean water. Their larva has no siphon tube and lies parallel to the undersurface of water. They tend to sit with their heads low and their rare ends raised high, especially when feeding.
subject: PSM

question_text: A patient presented with fever, headache, and retro-orbital pain for 3 days. He tested positive for the NS1 antigen. Which of the following mosquitoes transmits the disease he's suffering from?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the positive NS1 antigen test is suggestive of dengue fever. It is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito, which is also called as tiger mosquito.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by Aedes mosquito?
explanation: Japanese encephalitis and West Nile fever are transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. Chikungunya, yellow fever, and rift valley fever are transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
subject: PSM

question_text: A banker who is scheduled to travel to Congo is advised to take the yellow fever vaccine. What is the flight range of the mosquito which transmits this disease?
explanation: Yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. Its flight range is 100 metres.
subject: PSM

question_text: A patient with fever and mucosal bleeding is diagnosed with dengue fever. Which of the following is false about the mosquito which transmits this disease?
options: Development of larva from egg does not require water
It has a striped body pattern
explanation: Dengue fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. The conversion from the egg stage to the larval stage of this mosquito requires water. Eggs of any mosquito species do not survive without water. But the eggs of Aedes mosquitoes lie dormant in dry conditions for up to about nine months. They can hatch if exposed to favourable conditions such as water and food.
subject: PSM

question_text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever and headache for 5 days. Serological examination shows the presence of IgM antibodies to the JE virus. Which of the following mosquitoes transmits this disease?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes like Culex tritaeniorhynchus
subject: PSM

question_text: Match the following diseases and the mosquitoes which transmit them.
options: - c, ll - a, lll - d, iV - b
- a, ll - b, lll - c, lV - d
- b, ll - c, lll - d, lV - a
- d, ll - a, lll - b, lV - c
explanation: The correctly matched diseases with the mosquitoes which transmit them are: Disease Mosqu ito Yellow fever Aedes Bancroftian filariasis Culex Malaria Anoph eles Malayan filariasis Manso nia
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is true about pathogenic mosquitoes?
explanation: Aedes and Anopheles lay eggs singly. Culex lays eggs in rafts and Mansonia lays eggs in star-shaped clusters. Anopheles has spotted wings while the other pathogenic species have unspotted wings. Aedes transmits yellow fever, dengue and chikungunya. Culex is the main vector for JE and filariasis.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are posted in a PHC in a coastal region as a part of your rural postings. Which of the following Anopheles species is most commonly found here?
explanation: Anopheles stephensi and Anopheles sundaicus are found in coastal regions. Anopheles stephensi is also the main vector of malaria in urban regions. Anopheles culicifacies and Anopheles philippinensis are found in the plains. Anopheles fluviatilis and Anopheles minimus are found in foot-hill regions.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following species of Anopheles mosquitoes transmits urban malaria?
explanation: Urban malaria is transmitted by Anopheles stephensi.
subject: PSM

question_text: What is the distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes?
explanation: The distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes is 400 metres. This helps in limiting the spread of vector-borne diseases to new geographic regions.
subject: PSM

question_text: Identify the following vector.
explanation: The given image is of a housefly, whose scientific name is Musca domestica.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a method of disease transmission by houseflies?
explanation: Houseflies do not transmit diseases by biting. They transmit diseases by mechanical transmission by their legs or feet, vomit drop, and defecation. They transmit a variety of diseases like: Typhoid Polio Dysentery Amoebiasis Anthrax Yaws
subject: PSM

question_text: Which disease is transmitted by the following vector that is found in cracks and crevices of walls in the day time?
explanation: The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis. Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases: Kala-azar Oriental sore Sandfly fever Oroya fever Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.
subject: PSM

question_text: Sandfly does not transmit:
explanation: Trench fever is not transmitted by sandflies. It is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella quintana.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
explanation: The vector shown in the image is a tsetse fly. It transmits African sleeping sickness (African human trypanosomiasis). Tsetse flies belong to the genus Glossina. They have not demonstrated insecticide resistance. Methods of tsetse fly control include spraying of DDT, clearing of vegetation, destruction of wild game and genetic control.
subject: PSM

question_text: A patient presents with blurring of vision and a painless swelling over his left elbow which has gradually been increasing in size over the past 1 year. On examination, he is noted to have patchy depigmentation on his legs. Which of the following vectors transmits the disease he's suffering from?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. It is transmitted by blackfly. The usual presentation of onchocerciasis is the formation of a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients also present with patchy depigmentation on the legs called leopard skin. The presence of microfilaria in the eye causes photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestations are sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which can lead to blindness. Blackfly is also called Simulium. It has a flight range of almost 100 miles, making control of adult flies difficult. Abate is widely used as a larvicidal insecticide. The image given below shows a blackfly.
subject: PSM

question_text:
Spot the wrongly matched arthropod and disease.
Housefly – Poliomyelitis
explanation: Blackflies (Simulium) are the vector for onchocerciasis and not Chaga's disease. An arthropod or an invertebrate that transmits infection is called a vector. It transmits infection by: Inoculation into or through the skin or mucous membrane Biting Deposit of infective materials on skin or food or other objects Note: Chagas disease is transmitted by the reduviid bugs or kissing bugs or triatomines. Medical Entomology - Ticks, Fleas and Mites
subject: PSM

question_text: A veterinarian with fever, chills, and myalgia is diagnosed with Q fever. Which of the following is the most common reservoir of this disease?
explanation: Ticks are the most common reservoir of Q fever. Coxiella burnetii is the causative pathogen. The most commonly identified sources of human infection are farm animals, such as cattle, goats, and sheep. Infected mammals shed C. burnetii in their urine, feces, milk, and placenta. Human exposure to C. burnetii may occur as a result of inhalation of contaminated aerosols arising from the placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions on the surface of newborn animals. People working with farm animals and veterinarians are at a higher risk of infection.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not transmitted by hard ticks?
explanation: Relapsing fever is not transmitted by hard ticks, but by soft ticks.
subject: PSM

question_text: Peripheral smear of a patient with high grade fever, arthralgia, and myalgia is given below. Which of the following transmits this disease?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with peripheral smear showing maltese cross appearance is suggestive of babesiosis. It is transmitted by ticks.
subject: PSM

question_text: A patient with fever and joint pain presented with the following lesion on his left leg. Which of the following transmits this disease?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the image showing bulls eye rash is suggestive of Lyme disease. It is transmitted by Ixodes tick.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not true about the vector in the given image?
explanation: The given image is of a soft tick. It can withstand starvation for over a year. The head of the soft tick lies ventrally and it does not have a scutum. It serves as a reservoir for Q fever and transmits relapsing fever.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false about the vector in the given image?
options: Its nymphal stage has seven stages
It lays hundreds of eggs at once
explanation: The given image is of a hard tick. The hard tick has only one nymphal stage. It has a hard chitinous shield called the scutum which covers the entire back in males a small portion in the front in females. It feeds night and day and cannot withstand starvation. It lays several hundreds or thousands of eggs in one sitting.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following are also known as chiggers?
explanation: Larval forms of trombiculid mites are also known as chiggers. They are spider-like arthropods which are vectors for scrub typhus. The image given below shows trombiculid mite.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
explanation: The given image is of a reduviid bug. It transmits American trypanosomiasis, also known as Chagas disease. Reduviid bug is also known as the kissing bug or triatomine bug. It lives in cracks, fissures and other spaces in the walls and ceilings of human dwellings. Residual spraying with HCH or dieldrin is used for the control of these bugs. Option B: African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) is transmitted by the tsetse fly. Option C: Onchocerciasis is transmitted by the blackfly (Simulium). Option D: Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is transmitted by the sandfly.
subject: PSM

question_text: A 10-year-old boy presents with complaints of nocturnal pruritus. Examination shows burrows over the skin of his hands. KOH mount prepared from these lesions is given below. Which of the following vectors transmits this disease?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and KOH mount showing the itch mite are suggestive of scabies. It is transmitted by itch mite or Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the epidermis where it breeds. It is a small parasite, barely visible to the naked eye, with 4 pairs of legs. Its life cycle consists of four stages—egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages. Its spread can be through close contact or contaminated clothes. Benzyl benzoate is very effective as a sarcopticide. HCH, tetmosol, and sulphur ointments are also used. The image given below shows itch mite.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by mites?
explanation: Kyasanur forest disease is not transmitted by mites. It is a viral hemorrhagic fever transmitted by hard ticks. Scabies, scrub typhus, and rickettsial pox are transmitted by mites.
subject: PSM

question_text: You are given the following slide during your community medicine practicals. Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by this vector?
explanation: The above image is of a head louse. It does not transmit endemic typhus which is transmitted by fleas. Lice transmit epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, and trench fever.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by lice?
explanation: Epidemic typhus is transmitted by lice and caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. Murine typhus is transmitted by the rat flea. Tick typhus is transmitted by a hard tick. Scrub typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mite.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not transmitted by lice?
explanation: Q fever is not transmitted by lice. It is spread by the inhalation of contaminated aerosols containing Coxiella burnetti. Soft ticks are the most common reservoirs of Q fever. The aerosols arise from the placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions on the surface of newborn animals.
subject: PSM

question_text: Identify the following vector which transmits murine typhus.
explanation: The given image is of a rat flea-Xenopsylla cheopis. It transmits murine typhus.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by rat fleas?
explanation: Pneumonic plague is not transmitted by rat fleas. It is transmitted by inhalation of aerosolized droplets. Rat fleas are vectors for murine or endemic typhus, bubonic plague, and hymenolepiasis caused by Hymenolepis nana and Hymenolepis diminuta.
subject: PSM

question_text: A flea survey is being conducted in an area prone to outbreaks of plague. Which of the following indices is not used for this purpose?
explanation: Incidence of plague is not an index used in flea surveys. Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are: General flea index Specific flea index Percentage incidence of flea species Rodent infestation rate
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is true about sand fleas?
explanation: Sand fleas cause ulcers in the feet. They are also called jigger or chigoe fleas. The species called Tunga penetrans is of particular importance as it causes tungiasis. The fertilized female burrows into the skin of the feet, often beneath the nail and causes ulcers. Tetanus and gas gangrene frequently occur because of secondary infection. They flourish best in sandy soil and are found in the western parts of India. The below image shows a sand flea.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
explanation: The given image is of a cyclops or water flea. It is the vector for guinea worm disease or dracunculiasis and fish tapeworm infection. Humans are infected with these diseases by drinking water that contains cyclops. Its average life span is 3 months. Physical methods like straining and boiling of water can ensure the killing of this organism. Chemicals that can be used to control cyclops are chlorine, lime, and abate. Biological methods include Gambusia fish and barbel fish.
subject: PSM

question_text:
Which of the following diseases is not associated with rodents?
Trichinosis
explanation: Ascariasis is not associated with rodents. Diseases related to rodents are: Bacterial - Plague Tularemia Salmonellosis Leptospirosis Rat-bite fever Viral - Lassa fever Encephalitis Hemorrhagic fever Rickettsial - Scrub typhus Endemic typhus Rickettsial pox Parasitic - Hymenolepis diminuta Leishmaniasis Amoebiasis Trichinosis Chagas disease Fungal - Histoplasmosis Ringworm Methods of Pest Control
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following would you advise as the best approach to control arthropods?
explanation: Environmental control is the best approach to control arthropods. The principles of arthropod control include: Environmental control - Best approach Chemical control - Use of insecticides, pesticides, etc. Biological control - Use of larvivorous fish like Gambusia Genetic contro Newer methods - Chemosterilants Insect growth regulators Sex attractants Integrated approach involves usage of more than one modality of arthropod contro
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is the best method to control houseflies?
explanation: The best method to control houseflies is environmental control by the elimination of breeding places. They have shown resistance to a number of insecticides, including DDT.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not an organo-phosphate insecticide?
explanation: Dieldrin is an organo-chlorine insecticide. It is a broad-spectrum insecticide that acts as a contact, stomach, and inhalation poison.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not an aryl organo-phosphate insecticide?
explanation: Malathion is an alkyl organophosphate insecticide. It is used as an ultra-low volume spray in mosquito control.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following insecticides is least toxic to man?
explanation: Among the given options, malathion is the least toxic to man. It is the least toxic organo-phosphate insecticide.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false about fenthion?
options: It is used as a residual spray
It is used as a repellent
explanation: Fenthion is not used as a repellant. A commonly used repellant is N,N-diethyl-m-toluamide (DEET) that is used for protection from mosquitoes and ticks. Fenthion is a broad-spectrum insecticide that acts as both contact and stomach poison. It is used as a larvicide in mosquito control and also as a residual spray.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is false about pyrethrum?
options: Residual action as good as DDT
Can be used synergistically with DDT
explanation: Pyrethrum does not have a residual action like DDT or other synthetic insecticides. So, most space sprays contain pyrethrum and DDT for synergistic action. Pyrethrum is a natural insecticide of vegetable origin. It is extracted from the flowers of Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. It kills adult mosquitoes and other insects instantly on mere contact.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following cannot be used to describe pyrethrum?
explanation: Pyrethrum is not used as a residual spray. It is a contact and nerve poison that is also used as a space spray.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide?
explanation: Permethrin is a synthetic pyrethroid. Pyrethroids are synthetic insecticides, which are derived from naturally occurring pyrethrins. Pyrethroids modify the sodium channels in neuronal membranes and thereby disrupt the electrical signalling in the nervous system.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following vectors has not shown resistance to synthetic pyrethroids, in a widespread manner in India yet?
explanation: Sandflies (Phlebotomus) have not shown resistance to synthetic pyrethroids, in a widespread manner in India yet.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following best describes DDT?
explanation: DDT is a contact poison that belongs to the organochlorine family. It has been widely used but a number of organisms have become resistant to its effects now.
subject: PSM

question_text: During a dengue outbreak, the municipal corporation plans a DDT spraying initiative. Which of the following is false about this insecticide?
options: Para-para isomer is the most active fraction
It has residual action up to 18 months
It causes immediate death of insects
explanation: DDT does not cause the immediate death of insects. It takes several hours for its action to be complete. It contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomer that is the most active fraction of DDT. It acts on the nervous system of insects. The residual action of DDT may last as long as 18 months depending upon the treated surface.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is true about the usage of Paris green for mosquito control?
options: Harmful in normal doses to man and animals
explanation: Paris green is very effective against surface-feeding Anopheles. It is an anti-larval measure and is a stomach poison. It is not harmful in normal doses to man and animals.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following mosquitoes can be controlled by destroying aquatic plants with herbicides?
explanation: Mansonia mosquitoes breed in water with aquatic vegetation, and destroying this vegetation with herbicides would control this mosquito.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which of the following is not a mosquito anti-larval measure?
explanation: Pyrethrum is an anti-adult measure and not an anti-larval measure. Mineral oils, Gambusia, and Paris green are anti-larval measures used in mosquito control.
subject: PSM

question_text: Which among the following insecticides is most widely used as a space spray?
explanation: The insecticide most widely used as a space spray is pyrethrum.

I – c, II – a, III – b, IV – d

question_text: To curb an outbreak of plague in your locality, the municipal corporation decides to use rodenticides. Which of the following can be given as a single dose for this purpose?
explanation: Zinc phosphide is a single-dose rodenticide that causes death in a one-time exposure. Acute or single-dose rodenticides are classified according to the precautions that need to be taken before their use: Those requiring ordinary care - Red squill, norbormide, zinc phosphide Those requiring maximal precaution - Sodium fluoroacetate, fluoroacetamide and strychnine Too dangerous for use - Arsenic trioxide, phosphorus, thallium sulphate Multiple-dose or cumulative rodenticides cause death after multiple times of exposure. Examples include: Warfarin Coumafury Diphacinone Pindone
